questions.text: A 25-year-old man presents with weight loss and fever. The patient reports a history of blood in the stool and vomiting two weeks ago. Upon examination, tenderness is noted in the right hypochondrium along with an enlarged liver (hepatomegaly). An abdominal CT scan reveals a lesion in the right liver lobe characterized by irregular borders, several partitions, and varied densities. What is the most probable diagnosis? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Amoebic liver abscess

 

The most probable diagnosis in this case is C) Amoebic liver abscess.

 

1. Clinical Presentation:

 

  • The patient presents with weight loss and fever, which are common symptoms associated with liver abscesses.
  • A history of blood in the stool and vomiting two weeks ago may suggest an underlying gastrointestinal infection, likely to be amebic colitis.

 

2. Physical Examination Findings:

 

  • Tenderness in the right hypochondrium (upper right abdomen) suggests liver involvement.
  • Enlarged liver (hepatomegaly) is a common finding in liver abscesses.

 

3. Imaging Findings:

 

  • The description of the lesion on the abdominal CT scan is characteristic of an amoebic liver abscess. These abscesses typically have irregular borders, several partitions (internal septations), and varied densities due to necrotic tissue and pus formation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pyogenic liver abscess: Can also cause similar symptoms and imaging findings but will often present with high grade fever and chills, and is usually multiple.

 

Option B. Hydatid cyst: Typically presents as a well-defined cystic lesion on imaging and is caused by the Echinococcus parasite. It will not be preceded by a colitis type of event. It's less likely given the description of irregular borders and partitions in the lesion.

 

Option D. Hemangiomas: Hemangiomas are usually benign vascular tumors and are unlikely to cause the presented symptoms or imaging findings.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The combination of clinical symptoms, physical examination findings, and the characteristic imaging features of an irregular, partitioned lesion in the liver makes amoebic liver abscess the most probable diagnosis in this case

 

 

ANCHOVY SAUCE ‚Äì STERILE PUS SEEN IN AMEBIC LIVER ABSCESS

questions.text:
Which of the following statements is true regarding memantine? (INICET NOV 2022)
 

1. Its therapeutic effect is due to its antagonistic action on NMDA receptors.
 

2. It is reserved for moderate-to-severe cases of Alzheimer’s disease.
 

3. It is used only as a monotherapy and should not be used with cholinesterase inhibitors.
 

4. It is given at a daily dose of 20-30 mg/day.
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 1, 2

 

1. Its therapeutic effect is due to its antagonistic action on NMDA receptors: True. Memantine is an NMDA (N-methyl-D-aspartate) receptor antagonist. It works by blocking the action of glutamate at the NMDA receptors, which is thought to play a role in the symptoms of Alzheimer's disease.

 

2. It is reserved for moderate-to-severe cases of Alzheimer’s disease: True. Memantine is typically used in the treatment of moderate to severe Alzheimer's disease. It is not commonly used in the early stages of the disease.

 

Other Options:

 

3. It is used only as a monotherapy and should not be used with cholinesterase inhibitors: False. Memantine can be used alone (as monotherapy) or in combination with cholinesterase inhibitors, such as donepezil, rivastigmine, or galantamine, in the treatment of Alzheimer's disease.

 

4. It is given at a daily dose of 20-30 mg/day: False. Memantine is started at a lower dose of 5 mg daily and is titrated up to a target dose, which is usually 20 mg/day. Therefore, it is more precise to say that the standard dose is up to 20 mg/day.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Memantine is an NMDA receptor antagonist used for moderate to severe Alzheimer's disease. It can be used alone or in combination with cholinesterase inhibitors, and the standard maximum dose is 20 mg/day.

questions.text: A 37-year-old male patient presents to the surgical emergency with a history of peptic ulcer disease and pain in abdomen, bloating, and obstipation for 3 days. What is the next line in management? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) All of the above

 

Given scenario of history of peptic ulcer disease with acute abdomen suggests a peptic ulcer perforation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. IV fluids: Administering intravenous (IV) fluids is essential to address potential dehydration or peritonitis, to stabilise the patient.

 

Option B. CECT abdomen (Contrast-enhanced computed tomography of the abdomen): Performing a CECT abdomen is a diagnostic step that can help identify the cause of the patient's symptoms, such as complications related to peptic ulcer disease, including perforation or other abdominal pathologies.

 

Option C. Exploratory laparotomy: An exploratory laparotomy may be necessary if the patient's condition deteriorates or if there are signs of a surgical emergency, such as peritonitis or suspected perforation.

 

In summary, option D is correct because it covers the initial steps in managing this patient comprehensively, including addressing fluid balance (IV fluids), diagnostic imaging (CECT abdomen), and considering surgical intervention (exploratory laparotomy) if indicated by the clinical presentation and imaging findings

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Perforation of a hollow viscus is a life-threatening condition caused by the rupture of the alimentary tract.
  • This results in the leakage of enteric contents, leading to acute bacterial peritonitis.
  • Clinical features include abdominal pain and distension, nausea, vomiting, tachycardia, tenderness, rebound tenderness, decreased or absent bowel sounds, and guarding on palpation.
  • Investigations include estimating the white blood cell count, urea, serum electrolytes, and an erect abdominal radiograph showing free gas under the diaphragm.
  • CECT is the most sensitive investigation to detect minimal/suspected pneumoperitoneum.
  • Management includes IV fluids and exploratory laparotomy.

questions.text: A male patient who just lost his work felt irritated and depressed for the majority of the time. Thinking about the future troubled him, and he was irritated with his family members. He went out to see movies with his friends on occasion and was able to enjoy himself, but when he returned home, he experienced identical sensations. What's the most likely diagnosis? (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Adjustment disorder

 

The patient's symptoms ‚Äì depressive mood, irritability, and worry about the future ‚Äì began after a clear stressor, which in this case is the loss of his job. While he has some features of depression, the ability to temporarily feel better, such as when seeing movies with friends, makes a major depressive episode less likely.

 

This disorder arises within three months of a particular stressor (e.g., job loss) and resolves within six months after the stressor ends or the individual adapts.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Generalized anxiety disorder: Chronic worry is a feature, but there is usually no specific identifiable stressor or precipitant, and the duration of symptoms should be at least 6 months.

 

Option C. Mixed anxiety with depression: This isn‚Äôt a specific DSM-5 diagnosis. While the patient has symptoms of both, the clear onset after job loss points more towards adjustment disorder.

 

Option D. Moderate depression: The patient‚Äôs ability to still experience pleasure (e.g., enjoying movies) makes a full depressive episode less likely.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Adjustment disorder is characterized by emotional responses to stressful events like financial problems, medical illness, relationship problems or death of a loved one. It manifests with emotional or behavioral symptoms which include depressed mood, anxiety, worry, a feeling of inability to cope and some degree of disturbance in individuals daily functioning. The symptoms typically remit within 6 months if the stressor has ended. Treatment of choice is supportive psychotherapy.

 

Reference: A Short Textbook of Psychiatry, 7th edition, Page No 112.

questions.text: During your clinical rotation in infectious diseases, a patient with dengue fever develops warning signs like abdominal pain, persistent vomiting, clinical fluid accumulation, and an increase in hematocrit with a decrease in platelet count. Which of the following is the cornerstone of management for a patient showing warning signs of dengue? [AIIMS NOV 2019]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) IV Fluids 

 

  • The mainstay treatment for patients with dengue showing warning signs is intravenous (IV) fluid therapy.
  • This approach is crucial to prevent progression to severe dengue, including dengue hemorrhagic fever (DHF) and dengue shock syndrome (DSS).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Platelets: Only indicated if there is severe thrombocytopenia (<10,000/mm¬≥) with active bleeding.

 

Option C. Cryoglobulins: Not relevant for dengue management.

 

Option D. FFP (Fresh Frozen Plasma): Not a primary treatment for dengue with warning signs.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Ligamentum flavum has high levels of: (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Elastin fibres

 

Explanation:

 

Ligamentum flavum has high levels of elastin fibres.

 

The ventral portions of the laminae of nearby vertebrae are connected by a network of ligaments called the Ligament flava. They make up a portion of the posterior surface of the spinal canal and primarily consist of elastic tissue. Because it contains a lot of elastin, it can be stretched by 80% without suffering any harm. The ligamentum flava helps with extension back to the anatomical position by helping to prevent laminae separation during flexion.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Type 1 collagen: Collagen is the primary structural protein, among the different types of collagen, Type 1 collagen is the most abundant. It's found in many tissues including skin, tendons, internal organs, and the organic part of bones. Its primary function is to provide tensile strength to these tissues. It forms strong fibers and is responsible for the strength of the tissue. However, while present in many areas of the body, Type 1 collagen is not the predominant component of the ligamentum flavum.

 

Option B. Type 2 collagen: Type 2 collagen is primarily found in cartilaginous tissues. Its main function is to provide resistance against intermittent pressure, making it ideal for cartilaginous structures like the intervertebral discs, hyaline cartilage, and the vitreous humor of the eye. Given that ligamentum flavum is not a cartilaginous structure, Type 2 collagen is not its predominant component.

 

Option C. Reticular fibers: Reticular fibers are a type of fiber in connective tissue composed of Type 3 collagen. These fibers form a mesh-like framework in various organs such as the liver, spleen, and lymph nodes. They provide a supportive framework for these and other organs. While they are present in various parts of the body, they are not the main component of the ligamentum flavum.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The ligamentum flavum, which connects the laminae of adjacent vertebrae, contains a high concentration of elastin fibers, which allows the ligament to stretch during spine flexion and then return to its original shape when the spine is extended.

 

This characteristic helps maintain the stability and alignment of the vertebral column. Thus, among the given options, elastin fibers are the predominant component of the ligamentum flavum.

questions.text: Dr. Sanjana is leading a health initiative in Karnataka, focusing on the prevention of anemia among adult women through the Anemia Mukth Bharath initiative. She needs to communicate the correct dosage of iron and folic acid supplementation. What is the recommended dose according to the guidelines? [AIIMS MAY 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) 60 mg elemental iron + 500 mcg folic acid weekly

 

  • As per the Anemia Mukth Bharat initiative guidelines, it is recommended for adult females to consume 60 mg of elemental iron along with 500 mcg of folic acid in tablet form on a weekly basis.
  • These tablets have a sugar-coated exterior and are colored red.

choices.text: There is hypertrophy of ductus arteriosus.
Coarctation distal to the origin of the left subclavian artery
Supply is from posterior to anterior thoracic artery.
Collaterals develop to supply upper limb.

questions.text: A child presents with cold feet and a history of wearing socks even in the summers. On examination, lower limb pulses are diminished as compared to the radial pulse. Prominent radio femoral delay is present. What is the underlying condition? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Coarctation distal to the origin of the left subclavian artery

 

The clinical presentation of cold feet, wearing socks even in summer, diminished lower limb pulses compared to radial pulses, and prominent radiofemoral delay is characteristic of coarctation of the aorta. This congenital condition is characterized by a narrowing (coarctation) of the aorta, typically just distal to the origin of the left subclavian artery at the ductus arteriosus.

 

Key Points:

 

  • Coarctation of the Aorta: This condition results in the obstruction of blood flow, leading to higher blood pressure in the upper limbs and lower blood pressure in the lower limbs. The radiofemoral delay is a classic sign.
  • Location of Coarctation:
    • Postductal Coarctation (Adult Type): The constriction occurs distal to the ductus arteriosus. This type is more common and leads to the development of collateral circulation to bypass the obstruction.
    • Predductal Coarctation (Infantile Type): The constriction occurs proximal to the ductus arteriosus, leading to different clinical features and often presenting in infancy.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Cold feet and preference for wearing socks may be due to poor perfusion in the lower extremities.
    • Diminished lower limb pulses and radiofemoral delay are hallmark signs.
    • Hypertension in the upper extremities due to the coarctation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hypertrophy of ductus arteriosus: This condition does not cause radiofemoral delay or the constellation of symptoms seen in coarctation of the aorta.

 

Option C. Supply from posterior to anterior thoracic artery: This does not explain the clinical presentation, especially the radiofemoral delay.

 

Option D. Collaterals develop to supply upper limb: Collateral circulation is a compensatory mechanism that develops over time in coarctation of the aorta, primarily to supply blood to the lower extremities, not just the upper limbs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Coarctation of the aorta typically presents with cold feet, diminished lower limb pulses, and radiofemoral delay due to a narrowing of the aorta distal to the origin of the left subclavian artery.

choices.text: Is commonly associated with concomitant hypothyroidism
Characterised by at least four distinct episodes per year

questions.text: Rapid cycling in bipolar disorder is characterised by all of the following features except: (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Occurs more commonly in men

 

  • Rapid cycling in bipolar disorder is defined by having four or more distinct mood episodes (mania, hypomania, or depression) within a single year.
  • This condition is more commonly observed in females.
  • Several factors, including hypothyroidism and substance abuse, can contribute to the likelihood of rapid cycling.
  • Additionally, the use of antidepressants has been found to increase the risk of triggering rapid cycling episodes.
  • Mood stabilizer of choice - Valproate

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Is commonly associated with concomitant hypothyroidism: This statement is correct. Hypothyroidism is known to be associated with an increased risk of rapid cycling in bipolar disorder.

 

Option C. Characterised by at least four distinct episodes per year: This statement is correct. The definition of rapid cycling specifically includes the occurrence of four or more mood episodes in one calendar year.

 

Option D. Antidepressants increase the likelihood: This statement is correct. The use of antidepressants can indeed increase the likelihood of rapid cycling in individuals with bipolar disorder.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rapid cycling in bipolar disorder is more commonly seen in females and is characterized by at least four distinct episodes per year.

choices.text: Lateral cutaneous nerve of thigh

questions.text: Which nerve is blocked when local anesthesia is given below the inguinal ligament during femoral vein catheterization?(INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Genitofemoral nerve

 

The genitofemoral nerve is blocked when local anesthesia is given below the inguinal ligament during femoral vein catheterization.

 

  • The genitofemoral nerve originates from the L1 and L2 ventral rami. It divides into the genital and femoral branches after crossing behind the ureter.
  • The genital branch enters the inguinal canal through the deep ring and accompanies the spermatic cord or round ligament. It exits the superficial inguinal ring and supplies the cremaster muscle and the skin of the external genitalia.
  • The femoral branch descends lateral to the external iliac artery to pass behind the inguinal ligament and enters the femoral sheath lateral to the femoral artery. It pierces the anterior wall of the femoral sheath and fascia lata, supplying them.

 

The genitofemoral nerve gives sensory supply to the anteromedial thigh via the femoral branch. The genital branch supplies the skin of the scrotum in males and mons pubis and labium majus in females. It also innervates the cremaster muscle via the genital branch and is responsible for the cremasteric reflex.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Femoral nerve: The femoral nerve arises from the posterior division of the L2-L4 spinal segments. It lies outside the femoral sheath and enters the femoral triangle lateral to the femoral artery. Since it lies outside the femoral sheath, it is not involved in femoral vein catheterization.

 

Option C. Lateral cutaneous nerve of the thigh: This nerve provides sensory innervation to the anterolateral thigh. Injury to this nerve leads to meralgia paresthetica, causing pain and paresthesia in this region, but it does not relate to the femoral vein catheterization procedure.

 

Option D. Ilioinguinal nerve: The ilioinguinal nerve is most commonly injured during open hernia repair due to traction or thermal injury. It supplies the root of the penis and the scrotum, but is not relevant for femoral vein catheterization.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The genitofemoral nerve is blocked when local anesthesia is administered below the inguinal ligament during femoral vein catheterization. This nerve provides sensory innervation to the anteromedial thigh, scrotum in males, and mons pubis in females, and is responsible for the cremasteric reflex. Understanding the anatomy of the inguinal region and its relation to the femoral triangle is crucial in procedures involving catheterization or surgery in this area.

questions.text: Devices which are not used in colorimetric test? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) RBC pipette

 

Explanation:

 

The tools shows is the Sahli's method for hemoglobin estimation, a type of colorimetric test.

 

RBC pipette: This device is specifically designed for counting red blood cells and is marked with a red bead. It is not used in hemoglobin estimation via the colorimetric method. The RBC pipette plays no role in this test, which is why it is the correct answer for the device that is not used in this process.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Comparator: This is used to compare the color intensity of the hemoglobin solution with standard color shades to estimate the hemoglobin concentration.

 

Option C. Hemoglobinometer tube: A crucial component of the Sahli's hemoglobinometer, this tube is marked for measuring hemoglobin concentration in percentage and grams per deciliter.

 

Option D. N/10 HCl: This reagent is used to convert hemoglobin into acid hematin, which can then be measured using the colorimetric method.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The RBC pipette is not used in the Sahli's method of hemoglobin estimation, which employs a colorimetric test involving the hemoglobinometer tube, comparator, and N/10 HCl.

choices.text: 2 FC and 1 FAB fragment
1 Variable chain and 1 constant chain
1 Fc and 2 Fab fragments

questions.text: When papain acts on a molecule of immunoglobulin, which of the following are the end products? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1 Fc and 2 Fab fragments

 

When papain acts on a molecule of immunoglobulin, the end products are 1 Fc and 2 Fab fragments.

 

If an antibody molecule is digested with papain, cleavage occurs above the disulfide bonds that hold the heavy chains together. This generates 3 separate fragments, two of which are called Fab (fragment antigen binding), and one of which is called Fc (fragment crystallizable).

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

When an immunoglobulin molecule is digested with papain, the end products are 1 Fc fragment and 2 Fab fragments.

questions.text: What is the angle subtended by the largest alphabet on the Snellen's chart at 60m distance?(AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 5

 

The angle subtended by the largest alphabet on the Snellen‚Äôs chart at 60m distance is 5 minutes.

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The largest letter on a Snellen chart subtends an angle of 5 minutes of arc at any standard testing distance is essential for interpreting visual acuity results correctly. This standardization is fundamental in diagnosing and measuring visual acuity across different settings and distances

questions.text: Which organism moves transcellularly by utilizing actin filaments? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Listeria

 

Explanation:

 

Listeria monocytogenes moves within and between cells by polymerizing host actin filaments, forming "comet tails" that propel the bacterium.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. EIEC (Enteroinvasive E. coli): Invades intestinal cells but does not utilize actin filaments for intracellular movement.

 

Option C. Salmonella: Invades cells but moves intracellularly via different mechanisms, not actin-based motility.

 

Option D. Vibrio: Known for cholera; does not utilize actin for intracellular movement.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Listeria monocytogenes uniquely utilizes actin filaments for intracellular movement, a key feature distinguishing it from other enteric pathogens like EIEC, Salmonella, and Vibrio.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male with a history of recurrent sinusitis presents with decreased vision, eye protrusion, and fever. A computed tomography (CT) scan was done. What is the most likely diagnosis? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Orbital cellulitis with sinusitis

 

Involves the contents of the orbit including fat and muscle, often secondary to sinus infections, particularly the ethmoid sinus.

 

Symptoms include painful eye movements, protrusion of the eyeball (proptosis), decreased vision, and fever.

 

This condition can be sight-threatening and requires urgent treatment.

 

  • For the 35-year-old male patient with a history of recurrent sinusitis presenting with decreased vision, eye protrusion, and fever, the diagnosis of Orbital cellulitis with sinusitis is most consistent with the symptoms and the findings on the computed tomography (CT) scan. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Preseptal Cellulitis with Sinusitis: Involves the eyelid and skin anterior to the orbital septum, typically without eye protrusion or vision changes.Fever and eyelid swelling are common, but the involvement of the eye as described suggests a deeper infection.

 

Option C. Subperiosteal Abscess: This is an accumulation of pus between the orbit and the periosteum of the orbital bones, typically a complication of orbital cellulitis. It may lead to eye protrusion and restricted eye movements, but it's typically identified on imaging as a distinct abscess rather than generalized infection signs.

 

Option D. Cellulitis: A broad term that can refer to any soft tissue infection but without specifying involvement of the orbital area in relation to the sinuses would be less specific compared to orbital cellulitis with sinusitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Orbital cellulitis with sinusitis is a serious condition that requires immediate medical attention to prevent complications such as vision loss, intracranial spread of infection, and other severe outcomes.

questions.text: Which component of cement causes allergic contact dermatitis among construction workers in India? (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Chromate

 

  • It is a component of chromium, is commonly used in the manufacturing of cement and is a well-known cause of allergic contact dermatitis (ACD) among construction workers due to their frequent and prolonged exposure to wet cement.
  • Chromate can cause ACD through a type IV delayed hypersensitivity reaction.
  • When cement containing chromate comes into contact with the skin, particularly in the presence of moisture, the chromate can leach out and result in sensitization and subsequent dermatitis.
  • Allergic contact dermatitis is an inflammatory response to an allergen that only manifests as an eruption in people who have already been sensitized to the allergen.
  • The diagnosis of ACD is made by Patch test with the culprit substances.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cobalt: Cobalt is less commonly a cause of ACD in construction workers compared to chromate. Cobalt may be present in tools or dyes, but not typically in cement.

 

Option B. Nickel: Nickel is a well-known cause of ACD, often associated with exposure to nickel-containing jewellery or clothing items, not with cement.

 

Option C. Iron: Iron, while common in construction materials, is not a frequent cause of ACD. It is not known to be an allergen that would typically induce contact dermatitis.

 

 

 

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Among construction workers in India, allergic contact dermatitis is most commonly caused by chromate in cement, due to a type IV hypersensitivity reaction when chromate comes into contact with the skin.

 

 

Ref - Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition Chapter 128 page no 128.2-14

Online source: https://europepmc.org/article/pmc/2965911

choices.text: Presence of Anti-HBc IgM antibodies
Presence of IgM anti-HDV antibodies
Presence of Anti-HBc IgG antibodies

questions.text: Serologic findings of a patient with hepatitis are given below. HBsAg positive, Anti-HBc (total) positive, Anti-HDV (total) positive. Which of the following is most useful in diagnosing HDV co-infection over superinfection? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Presence of Anti-HBc IgM antibodies

 

To differentiate between HDV co-infection and superinfection, it is essential to understand the nature of these infections:

 

  • Co-infection occurs when a patient acquires both acute HBV and acute HDV simultaneously. The presence of Anti-HBc IgM antibodies indicates a recent acute HBV infection, which is characteristic of co-infection.
  • Superinfection occurs when a patient with chronic HBV infection acquires an acute HDV infection. In this scenario, the patient has markers of chronic HBV (like Anti-HBc IgG antibodies) along with markers of acute HDV infection.

 

The Anti-HBc IgM antibodies are indicative of an acute HBV infection and are useful for diagnosing co-infection because they show that the HBV infection is recent, which aligns with the scenario of both HBV and HDV being acquired simultaneously.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. High HDV viral load: This can be present in both co-infection and superinfection and does not specifically differentiate between the two.

 

Option C. Presence of IgM anti-HDV antibodies: These antibodies can be present in both co-infection and superinfection as they indicate an acute HDV infection. Therefore, they are not useful in differentiating between the two conditions.

 

Option D. Presence of Anti-HBc IgG antibodies: This indicates a past or chronic HBV infection. The presence of Anti-HBc IgG is more consistent with superinfection rather than co-infection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of Anti-HBc IgM antibodies is most useful in diagnosing HDV co-infection over superinfection because it indicates a recent acute HBV infection, which is characteristic of co-infection.

questions.text: A community with a population of 20,000 documented 456 births in a year, of which 56 were stillbirths. The total number of deaths in the community for that year was 247, including 56 deaths within the first 28 days of life and 34 additional deaths after 28 days but before completing the first year of life. What is the infant mortality rate (IMR) for this community? [AIIMS NOV 2019]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) 225

 

 

In the given question, out of total 456 births, 56 were dead born. 

 

Therefore, the number of live births= 456-56 = 400.

 

In the same year, it is given that the number of deaths before 28 days is 56, and the number of deaths after 28 days but before 1 year is 34.

 

Hence, the total number of deaths of children < 1 year is 56 + 34 = 90

 

IMR = (90x1000)/400 = 900/4 = 225

 

Hence, the IMR is 225 per 1000 live births.

 

INFANT MORTALITY RATE

 

  • It is the number of deaths per 1000 live births of children under one year of age. It is the most sensitive indicator of availability and utilization of health care services in a country. Is most important indicator of health status of a community, level of living and effectiveness of MCH services in general. 
  • IMR is among ‚Äòthe best predictors of state failure‚Äô
  • It is a rate.
  • IMR of India (2023): 26.6 per 1000 live births; 
  • IMR of India - 35 per 1000 live births (NFHS-5 2019-21,); 28 per 1000 Live births (SRS, May 2022)
  • Is the second best indicator of socio-economic development of a country: Ultimate solution for lowering IMR lies in socio-economic development [Best indicator is U5MR]

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Infant Mortality Rate (IMR) for the community, calculated as the number of infant deaths per 1000 live births.
  • This rate serves as a crucial indicator of the health status and effectiveness of maternal and child health services in the community.

 

NOTE - UNICEF considers U5MR or CMR as ‚Äòsingle best indicator of socio-economic development and well-being‚Äô (even better than IMR)

questions.text: A person was brought dead, and an autopsy was performed to determine the cause of death. The following findings were noted on examination. What is the probable cause of death?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Throttling

 

Throttling refers to manual strangulation, where the perpetrator uses hands to compress the neck. This can result in death through several mechanisms:

 

  1. Occlusion of blood supply to the brain via compression of the carotid arteries, preventing oxygenated blood from reaching the brain.
  2. Airway occlusion, although this plays a minor role as the obstruction of blood flow is more critical.
  3. Carotid sinus pressure, which can lead to vagus nerve stimulation, potentially causing cardiac arrest due to vasovagal shock.

 

Signs observed in deaths due to asphyxia:

 

  • Petechial hemorrhages on the face, eyebrows, eyelids, forehead, ears, conjunctiva, and sclera. Petechial hemorrhages in the visceral pleura are referred to as Tardieu's spots.
  • Congested larynx with slight oozing of blood.
  • Marked venous congestion in internal organs.
  • Emphysematous and congested lungs with serosanguinous fluid in the alveoli.
  • Dark-colored blood due to CO‚ÇÇ accumulation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Strangulation:  This is a broad term encompassing deaths caused by violent asphyxia, such as in cases of ligature strangulation or throttling. However, throttling specifically refers to manual strangulation.

 

Option C. Hanging:  In hanging, there is typically a ligature mark on the neck, with possible injury to the cervical spine. The mechanism of asphyxia is different as it involves suspension rather than direct compression of the neck by hands.

 

Option D. Mugging : In mugging, the neck is compressed using the elbow or knee, often from behind. While asphyxia and struggle marks may be present, there is usually no visible evidence of violence on the neck, as the compression is applied with soft muscles, which leaves minimal external trauma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Throttling, or manual strangulation, results in asphyxia primarily by occluding blood flow to the brain and can cause petechial hemorrhages and marked venous congestion, which are distinct findings in autopsy.

questions.text: Which of the following is seen in UMN (Upper Motor Neuron) weakness? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hyper-reflexia

 

Upper Motor Neuron (UMN) lesions are associated with a specific set of clinical features due to the disruption of the central motor pathways that originate in the cerebral cortex and descend through the brainstem and spinal cord to synapse on the lower motor neurons. The key features of UMN lesions include:

 

  • Hyper-reflexia: This is characterized by exaggerated deep tendon reflexes. The loss of inhibitory modulation from the cortex leads to an overactive reflex arc.
  • Spasticity: Increased muscle tone that is velocity-dependent, often seen in conjunction with hyper-reflexia.
  • Babinski sign: An abnormal reflex where the big toe extends upward when the sole of the foot is stimulated.
  • No significant muscle atrophy: While mild disuse atrophy can occur over time, it is not as pronounced as in lower motor neuron (LMN) lesions.
  • No fasciculations: Fasciculations, or spontaneous contractions of muscle fibers, are indicative of LMN lesions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Atrophy: Significant muscle atrophy is a hallmark of LMN lesions due to denervation of the muscles. It is not typically seen in UMN lesions except for mild disuse atrophy.

 

Option C. Rigidity: Rigidity is associated with extrapyramidal disorders, such as Parkinson's disease, and is characterized by increased muscle tone that is uniform and not velocity-dependent.

 

Option D. Fasciculations: Fasciculations are indicative of LMN lesions and result from spontaneous depolarization of lower motor neurons.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The hallmark feature of Upper Motor Neuron (UMN) weakness is hyper-reflexia, characterized by exaggerated deep tendon reflexes. This occurs due to the loss of inhibitory control from the brain on the reflex arcs in the spinal cord.

questions.text: The following sets of X-rays are suggestive of:(INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ankylosing spondylitis

 

ANKYLOSING SPONDYLITIS

 

  • Also known as Marie-Strumpell or Bechterew‚Äôs disease.
  • It is a seronegative chronic inflammatory disease affecting the spine and sacroiliac joints.
  • HLA B27 is positive in 90% patients.
  • Sacroiliitis is the earliest manifestation with features of both enthesitis & synovitis.
  • Clinical Presentation:
    • It is most commonly seen in young males aged 15-25 years.
    • Most common symptom is dull backache, insidious in onset, associated with morning stiffness for few hours that improves with activity.
    • Question mark (?) posture due to hyperkyphosis of thoracic spine and loss of lumbar lordosis.
    • Cervical spine involvement is usually late and show forward stooping and loss of extension and rotation.
    • Hip and shoulder joint arthritis may occur.
    • Peripheral joints may also be involved in some.
    • Anterior uveitis is the most common extra-articular manifestation.
       
  • Spine radiograph:
    • Loss of lumbar lordosis (Straightening).
    • Haziness of sacroiliac (SI) joint margins is the earliest change.
    • Later on, SI joints show irregular subchondral erosions in, sclerotic articular margins, joint space widening and eventually bony ankylosis.
    • Calcification of supraspinous & interspinous ligaments (Dagger sign) and that of sacroiliac and sacrotuberous ligaments.
    • Enthesopathy: Calcification at the attachment of muscles, tendons & ligaments.
    • Trolley/Tram-track sign: Three linear radiopaque lines due to ligament calcification.
    • Erosions of anterior corners of vertebral body causing squaring of vertebral body.
    • Bridging osteophytes (syndesmophytes) with vertical orientation bridging vertebral bodies are seen. Bamboo spine appearance due to syndesmophytes.

 

 

Sacroiliitis

 

 

A. Trolley/Tram track sign; B. Bamboo Spine

 

 

Dagger Sign

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Paget‚Äôs disease. It is characterized by excessive disorganized bone turnover, that encompasses excessive osteoclastic activity initially followed by disorganized excessive new bone formation. It is the osteoclast that appears larger and irregular whereas osteoblast are relatively normal. The new bone formed is abnormal, very vascular and larger (deforms and fractures) than preexisting bone which leads to cortical widening and contributes to the deformity. Long bone X-ray shows deformity, enlargement or expansion of bone with cortical thickening coarsening of trabecular markings and lytic and sclerotic changes. Blade of grass lesion is seen. Skull X-ray reveal ‚Äúcotton wool‚Äù or osteoporosis circumscripta, thickening of diploic area. Vertebral cortical thickening at superior and inferior end plates creates a picture frame vertebrae and diffuse sclerosis causing ivory vertebrae. Pelvic radiograph shows sclerotic iliopectineal line (Brim sign), fusion or disruption of sacroiliac joints, etc.

 

 

Blade of grass appearance

 

 

 

 

Option C. Rheumatoid arthritis. In rheumatoid arthritis, upper cervical spine & hip joint are less commonly involved. There is atlantoaxial joint subluxation when cervical spine is involved. Lumbar spine is usually spared. The chronic inflammatory synovitis in the cervical spine results in severity that progresses to bone erosion and ligamentous laxity, leading to late spinal instability. The most common radiological presentations of spinal involvement in RA are: atlantoaxial subluxation, cranial settling (also known as basilar impression, atlantoaxial impaction or superior migration of the odontoid, the most severe form of spinal instability in RA), subaxial subluxation or a combination of them.

 

 

Option D. Hyperparathyroidism. Hyperparathyroidism maybe primary (due to adenoma or hyperplasia), secondary (due to persistent hypocalcemia) or tertiary (when secondary hyperplasia leads to autonomous overactivity). Parathyroid adenoma is most common cause of primary hyperparathyroidism. It presents with subperiosteal resorption, and replacement of endosteal cavitation marrow by vascular granulation and fibrous tissue (osteitis fibrosa cystica). Classical and pathognomic feature of hyperparathyroidism is subperiosteal cortical resorption of middle phalanges on radial aspect. Clinical features are Abdominal groans (dyspepsia), psychic moans, renal stones and weak bones (Groans, moans, stones and Bones). Hyperparathyroidism causes diffuse rarefaction of bone (osteopenia) and osteitis fibrosa cystica. Radiological Features includes subperiosteal resorption of terminal tufts of phalanges, lateral end of clavicle and symphysis pubis, loss of lamina dura (i.e. thin cortical bone of tooth socket surrounding teeth is seen as thin white line, is resorbed), irregular, diffuse rarefaction of bones, i.e. generalized osteopenia, thinning of cortices, and indistinct bony trabeculae, brown tumor, salt pepper appearance of skull.

 

 

 

Resorption of lamina dura

 

 

Salt-pepper skull

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

The radiographic images given the question shows:

 

A. Bamboo spine

 

B. Sacroiliitis

 

C. Loss of lumbar lordosis

 

D. Dagger‚Äôs sign

 

These features are characteristic of Ankylosing spondylitis.

questions.text: A boy with a history of a fall from a tree presents with a lurching gait and dragging of his feet. Which of the following structures are involved? (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 2

 

Explanation:

 

The structure involved in causing lurching gait in the child is gluteus medius (marked as 2). The gluteus medius muscle is critical for stabilizing the pelvis during gait. When functioning normally, it prevents the pelvis from dropping to the opposite side during the swing phase of the walk. If injured or dysfunctional, such as might occur from a traumatic fall, the ability to maintain pelvic stability is compromised, leading to a lurching gait, known clinically as a Trendelenburg gait.

 

 

The structure shown in the image are :

 

1-Gluteus maximus

2-Gluteus medius

3-Piriformis

4-Sciatic nerve

 

Other Options:

 

1. Gluteus Maximus: The largest and most superficial of the gluteal muscles, mainly responsible for extension and lateral rotation of the hip. Its involvement is more related to power movements like climbing or jumping rather than gait stability.

 

3. Piriformis: A small muscle located deep in the buttock, behind the gluteus maximus. It helps with lateral rotation of the hip. Although it is near the sciatic nerve, it is less likely involved in producing a lurching gait unless it compresses the sciatic nerve, causing sciatica.

 

4. Sciatic Nerve: The largest nerve in the body, running from the lower back to the feet. While injury to this nerve can cause pain and weakness in the legs, it typically would not cause a lurching gait unless there is significant associated muscle weakness.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Clinical Insight:

 

Injury to the gluteus medius or the superior gluteal nerve can lead to an inability to properly abduct the hip on the stance side, resulting in a drop of the pelvis on the contralateral side when the affected leg is weight-bearing. This is often demonstrated by a positive Trendelenburg sign and manifests as a compensatory lurch toward the affected side to maintain balance.

 

Additional Information

 

Gluteus medius and minimus are powerful abductors of the hip joint. Mechanism of actions of gluteus medius and minimus-

 

  • When the leg on one side is lifted off the ground, the gluteus medius and minimus muscles, on the opposite supported side, exert traction on the hip bone by acting from the femur. This action results in a slight raising of the pelvis on the unsupported side, which helps maintain the trunk in the upright position.
  • The actions of these muscles are affected when there is an injury to the superior gluteal nerve, neck of the femur, or loss of normal angulation of the shaft of the femur. This occurs in conditions like paralysis of the glutei, developmental dysplasia of the hip, etc.
  • When the gluteus medius and minimus are paralyzed, the pelvis sinks down on the unsupported (normal) side, when the patient tries to stand on the affected limb. This leads to a positive Trendelenburg's sign with a characteristic lurching gait - the patient lurches towards the affected side with contralateral pelvis drop.

choices.text: Both Assertion and Reason are independently true statements and the Reason is correct explanation for the Assertion
Both Assertion and Reason are independently true statements, but the Reason is not the correct explanation for the Assertion
Assertion is independently true statement, but reason is independently a false statement
Assertion is independently false statement, but reason is independently a true statement

questions.text:
Assertion: Larger doses of acyclovir are recommended for treating genital herpes in HIV.


Reason: Severe/frequent recurrences are seen in HIV patients.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Both Assertion and Reason are independently true statements and the Reason is correct explanation for the Assertion

 

Larger doses of acyclovir are indeed recommended for the treatment of genital herpes in HIV-infected individuals. The standard treatment regimens for herpes simplex virus (HSV) infections often require dose adjustments when the immune system is compromised, as in the case of HIV. This is because the weakened immune state in HIV patients can lead to more severe and frequent recurrences of genital herpes, making it necessary to use higher doses of antiviral medication like acyclovir for effective management and suppression of the virus.

 

The Reason explains this well: severe and frequent recurrences of genital herpes are common in individuals with HIV due to the compromised immune function. The reduced ability to control viral infections in HIV-positive patients results in more persistent and recurrent outbreaks of herpes, necessitating a more aggressive therapeutic approach. Therefore, the reason provided is accurate and directly supports the assertion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Larger doses of acyclovir are necessary for treating genital herpes in HIV-infected patients due to the increased frequency and severity of herpes recurrences in these individuals, caused by their compromised immune systems.

choices.text: It decreases ATP production and hence breaks the links between globin chains
Binds to the central cavity of hemoglobin surrounded by histidine and lysine and favours salt bridge formation

questions.text: 2,3 BPG causes unloading of oxygen to tissues because:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Binds to the central cavity of hemoglobin surrounded by histidine and lysine and favors salt bridge formation:

 

Option C. Binds to the central cavity of hemoglobin surrounded by histidine and lysine and favors salt bridge formation: This is the correct explanation. 2,3 BPG binds to a specific site in hemoglobin's central cavity, which is surrounded by histidine and lysine residues. This binding reduces hemoglobin's affinity for oxygen, favoring the release of oxygen molecules from hemoglobin into the surrounding tissues. The formation of salt bridges as a result of this binding contributes to the release of oxygen.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. It decreases ATP production and hence breaks the links between globin chains: This statement is not accurate. 2,3 BPG does not directly affect ATP production or break links between globin chains.

 

Option B. It increases ATP production: This statement is not correct. 2,3 BPG is not involved in ATP production.

 

Option D. Inhibits Taut structure formation: This statement is not accurate. 2,3 BPG does not inhibit the formation of the Taut structure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • 2,3 BPG is formed in RL shunt which has no net ATP production
  • 2,3-Bisphosphoglycerate (2,3-BPG) plays a crucial role in regulating oxygen delivery by binding to deoxyhemoglobin and stabilizing the T (taut) state, which has a lower affinity for oxygen, thereby promoting oxygen unloading to tissues.

 

 

  • When 2,3 BPG levels gets decreased, it promotes relaxed confirmation of Hb resulting in oxygen loading.

questions.text: Which of the following protein deficiency is responsible for Hereditary Angioedema? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) C1 inhibitor  

 

Hereditary angioedema (HAE) is a rare genetic disorder characterized by recurrent episodes of severe swelling (angioedema). The condition is caused by a deficiency or dysfunction of the C1 inhibitor protein. C1 inhibitor is crucial in regulating the complement system, particularly the classical pathway, by inhibiting the activity of C1 esterase. In the absence or dysfunction of C1 inhibitor, uncontrolled activation of the complement pathway occurs, leading to excessive production of bradykinin, a potent vasodilator that causes the symptoms of angioedema.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Decay accelerating factor: Also known as CD55, this protein is responsible for regulating the complement system on cell surfaces, preventing damage to host cells. Deficiency of CD55 is associated with Paroxysmal Nocturnal Hemoglobinuria (PNH), not hereditary angioedema.

 

Option C. CD59: This protein is also involved in the regulation of the complement system by inhibiting the formation of the membrane attack complex (MAC). Like CD55, CD59 deficiency is associated with Paroxysmal Nocturnal Hemoglobinuria (PNH), not hereditary angioedema.

 

Option D. C5 convertase: This is an enzyme complex that plays a role in the complement cascade by cleaving C5 into C5a and C5b, leading to the formation of the membrane attack complex. Deficiencies in components of C5 convertase can lead to increased susceptibility to infections, particularly with Neisseria species, but it is not associated with hereditary angioedema.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text:
Which of the following are branches of the anterior division of the internal iliac artery? (INICET May 2021)

 

1. Superior gluteal artery

2. Inferior gluteal artery

3. Superior vesical artery

4. Middle rectal artery

5. Inferior vesical artery

6. Vaginal artery
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 2, 3, 4, 5, 6

 

The internal iliac artery serves as a major artery supplying the pelvic organs, walls, and gluteal region. It divides into anterior and posterior divisions, each giving rise to specific branches that supply different pelvic structures. The branches of the anterior division typically supply the pelvic viscera and some pelvic walls.

 

 

Branches from the anterior division:

 

2. Inferior gluteal artery : Supplies the buttock and lower limb.

 

3. Superior vesical artery : Supplies the bladder and can contribute to the upper ureter and seminal vesicles.

 

4. Middle rectal artery : Supplies the rectum.

 

5. Inferior vesical artery : Supplies the bladder, prostate, and seminal vesicles in males; replaced by the vaginal artery in females.

 

6. Vaginal artery : Supplies the vagina and base of the bladder in females; it is often considered the female equivalent of the inferior vesical artery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The internal iliac artery is the major artery of the pelvis. At the superior border of the greater sciatic foramen in the pelvis, it divides into anterior and posterior trunks.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents with a mass in the right kidney on a CECT scan, as shown below. What is the diagnosis? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Renal cell carcinoma        

 

Explanation:

 

The case of an elderly man with a heterogeneous large renal mass in the CECT image suggests renal cell carcinoma (RCC). RCC often appears as a solid renal mass with areas of necrosis or hemorrhage that cause the heterogeneity in density seen on CT images. This type of cancer is the most common type of kidney cancer in adults and can present with various imaging appearances, but a large, irregular, and heterogeneous mass is highly suggestive.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Renal angiomyolipoma: Typically appears as a well-circumscribed mass with a significant fat component, which should show negative Hounsfield units (HU) on CT, which is not evident in the presented image.

 

Option B. Renal oncocytoma: Generally presents as a well-circumscribed, homogenous mass with a central scar. It does not typically appear as heterogeneous as RCC.

 

Option D. Renal cyst: Would appear as a fluid-filled structure with very well-defined borders and no solid components, which does not match the characteristics of the mass show

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 28-year-old male who has been admitted with symptoms of altered sensorium and hydrophobia, indicating a potential case of rabies, you have obtained corneal scrapings for further investigation. Now, which test would you select to establish a conclusive diagnosis of the condition? (INICET MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Viral Culture

 

Altered sensorium and hydrophobia is suggestive of rabies which can be diagnosed by viral culture from corneal scrapings.

 

 

Multiple tests in succession/simultaneously are the best. Usually, Direct Fluorescent Antibody test followed by virus isolation/culture is useful.

 

Virus isolation through culture: best specimens are brain and saliva. CSF, corneal smears and centrifuged urine can also be used.

 

Other Options

 

Option A: Serological tests like indirect immunofluorescence are insensitive.

 

Option B: Seller stain for negri bodies can only be demonstrated in brain (pyramidal cells of Ammon's horn, and the Purkinje cells of the cerebellum are the most common site).

 

Option D: Real time-PCR Amplification Detection of rabies virus RNA is highly sensitive and specific. This technique can detect virus in fresh saliva samples, skin, CS, and brain tissues. However, it is not confirmatory test.

 

Educational Objective

 

Viral culture from corneal scrapings is the most definitive test for diagnosing rabies in a patient presenting with altered sensorium and hydrophobia.

questions.text: Identify the condition shown in the image. (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Adenoid facies

 

The above given image shows adenoid facies. The characteristic features are visible which are: -

 

  • Elongated face with dull expression
  • Open mouth
  • Hitched up upper lip
  • Prominent upper teeth, which appear crowded
  • High arched hard palate
  • Pinched-in nose

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Goldenhar syndrome: Typically presents with abnormalities of the eye, ear, and spine, none of which are visible in this image.

 

Option C. Horse facies: Characterized by an elongated face with prominent jaw structures, which does not match the features in the image.

 

Option D. Frog facies: Often includes a wide mouth and bulging eyes, which are not present in this child.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Adenoid facies can be recognized by characteristic features such as elongated face, open mouth posture due to nasal obstruction, hitched up upper lip revealing crowded upper teeth, and a pinched-in nose. It's associated with chronic adenoid hypertrophy, impacting the facial structure and respiratory function.

questions.text: Which of the following has been reported to have endemic transmission in India? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever

 

Crimean-Congo haemorrhagic fever (CCHF) is a widespread disease caused by a tick-borne virus (Nairovirus) of the Bunyaviridae family. The CCHF virus causes severe viral haemorrhagic fever outbreaks, with a case fatality rate of 10‚Äì40%.

 

CCHF is endemic in Africa, the Balkans, the Middle East and Asian countries south of the 50th parallel north ‚Äì the geographical limit of the principal tick vector. Outbreak in Gujarat, India occurred in 2011.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Yellow fever is mostly endemic to the south and central America, and certain parts of Africa.

 

Option C. Ebola virus is located mainly in sub-Saharan Africa

 

Option D. Hendra virus mainly confined to north-eastern coast of Australia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever (CCHF) has been reported to have endemic transmission in India, specifically with an outbreak in Gujarat in 2011.

choices.text: Heat till it become red hot

questions.text: Inoculation loops are commonly sterilized by which method? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Heat till it becomes red hot

 

Inoculation loops are typically made of nichrome wire with a circular structure at one end and a wooden handle. The most appropriate method for sterilizing these loops is heating them until they become red hot, which is a type of physical heat method. This method ensures complete sterilization of the metal portion of the loop that comes in contact with microorganisms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Autoclaving:

 

  • Incorrect because autoclaving is not suitable for inoculation loops as it would be impractical and unnecessary
  • Autoclaving is primarily used for bulk sterilization of media, equipment, and materials at 121¬∞C for 15 minutes at 15 PSI

 

Option B. Microwave:

 

  • Incorrect because microwave sterilization is not appropriate for metal objects like inoculation loops
  • Microwaves can cause arcing with metal objects and potentially damage the equipment

 

Option C. Passing over flame 3 times:

 

  • Incorrect because this method is specifically used for degreasing glass slides
  • This technique would not provide sufficient heat to ensure complete sterilization of the inoculation loop

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Inoculation loops must be sterilized by heating till red hot to ensure complete elimination of microorganisms, as this is the most effective and practical physical heat method for these instruments.

questions.text: Match the following:(AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) A-3, B-4, C-5, D-1

 

Explanation:

 

A. Madelung deformity involves distal radius.  It is the volar translation of the wrist. It is seen associated with Turner Syndrome.

 

 

B. Haglund deformity is the bony prominence over calcaneum and the overlying retrocalcaneal bursitis.

 

 

C. Buttonhole deformity is the abnormal extension at distal interphalangeal joint and flexion at proximal interphalangeal joint and is seen with Rheumatoid arthritis.

 

 

D. Gunstock deformity is seen in Cubitus varus. It is a complication frequently seen after untreated supracondylar fracture of humerus.

 

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Drug resistant falciparum is seen in India
Presence of duffy blood group antigen is protective against vivax
Severe malaria with shock is called algid malaria
Relapse is seen in P. ovale

questions.text: Choose the wrong statement about Plasmodium species: (INICET MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Presence of duffy blood group antigen is protective against vivax

 

  • The absence, not the presence, of the Duffy blood group antigen, is protective against P. vivax because the Duffy antigen normally serves as the receptor for Plasmodium vivax.
  • Drug Efflux pumps are the primary mode of resistance for Chloroquine. It is mediated by an ABC transporter encoded by P. falciparum multidrug resistance gene 1 (Pfmdr1).
  • Algid malaria is a rare complication of severe malaria characterized by hemodynamic collapse manifesting as shock with pronounced metabolic changes and hypothermia.
  • Relapse is seen in cases of Plasmodium vivax and Plasmodium ovale.
  • Malaria relapse:
    • True relapse is caused due to Hypnozoites.
    • These are resting forms.
  • In the case of Plasmodium vivax and ovale two kinds of sporozoites are seen, some of which:
    • multiply inside hepatic cells to form - Schizonts
    • others persist and remain dormant as - hypnozoites
  • From time to time some are activated to become schizonts and release merozoites, which go on infecting RBCs producing clinical relapse.
  • In the case of Plasmodium falciparum and Plasmodium malaria, the initial tissue phase disappears completely and no hypnozoites are found, hence technically relapse is not seen.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Drug resistant falciparum is seen in India: This statement is correct. Drug-resistant strains of Plasmodium falciparum are a significant concern in India.

 

Option C. Severe malaria with shock is called algid malaria: This statement is correct. Algid malaria is a rare but severe complication of malaria characterized by shock and metabolic disturbances.

 

Option D. Relapse is seen in P. ovale: This statement is correct. Relapse is seen in Plasmodium ovale as well as Plasmodium vivax due to the presence of hypnozoites.

 

Educational Objective

 

The absence of the Duffy blood group antigen is protective against Plasmodium vivax, not its presence.

questions.text: A patient is brought with altered sensorium and seizures. Attendant shows the laboratory report which reveals elevated transaminases. Which of the following can be used in this condition? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Oxazepam
 

Oxazepam is a short acting Benzodiazepine, which has no active metabolites and can be used safely in a patient with active liver disease. Other BZDs that can be used include Temazepam, Lorazepam, Estazolam.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Midazolam: Midazolam is metabolized in the liver through oxidative pathways and produces active metabolites. It is not the best choice for patients with liver impairment.

 

Option B. Diazepam: Diazepam is metabolized in the liver to active metabolites, which can accumulate in patients with liver dysfunction, potentially leading to prolonged sedation and toxicity.

 

Option C. Alprazolam: Alprazolam is also metabolized in the liver through oxidative processes and has active metabolites. It is not recommended for patients with significant liver disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients with liver impairment, such as those with elevated transaminases, it is crucial to use medications that are not heavily reliant on hepatic metabolism and do not produce active metabolites. Oxazepam, being metabolized via conjugation, is a safer option in such scenarios compared to other benzodiazepines like midazolam, diazepam, and alprazolam.

 

Remember with mnemonic ‘STOLE’

 

Short-acting Benzodiazepines

 

  • Temazepam
  • Oxazepam
  • Lorazepam
  • Estazolam

questions.text: Which of the following muscles is not involved in the overhead abduction of the arm? (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Pectoralis major

 

  • Pectoralis major is mainly involved in flexion, adduction and medial rotation of the arm (at the shoulder joint) and is not involved in the abduction of the arm.
  • Glenohumeral abduction is about 120¬∞ or more. The glenohumeral arthrodesis restricts the abduction at about 45¬∞. Further abduction occurs at the sterno- and acromioclavicular articulations, and contralateral vertebral flexion.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Serratus Anterior: The serratus anterior muscle is involved in the overhead abduction of the arm. This muscle helps in the upward rotation of the scapula, allowing the arm to be raised overhead.

 

Option B. Deltoid: The deltoid muscle is a key muscle for overhead abduction of the arm. It has three distinct portions (anterior, middle, and posterior) that cover the shoulder joint. The middle portion of the deltoid is particularly responsible for abduction of the arm, lifting it away from the body.

 

Option C. Trapezius: The trapezius muscle also plays a role in the overhead abduction of the arm. The upper fibers of the trapezius assist in elevating the shoulder girdle, contributing to arm abduction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

PRINCIPLE MUSCLES ACTING ON SHOULDERS

questions.text: A preterm infant in the NICU was observed to have marked nasal flare, distinct xiphoid retractions, minimal intercostal retractions, and inspiratory lag with an audible grunt without a stethoscope. What would be the Silverman Anderson score? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 8

 

The Silverman-Anderson score is a clinical scoring system used to assess the degree of respiratory distress in neonates, particularly those with hyaline membrane disease (HMD) or other forms of respiratory distress syndrome (RDS). The score ranges from 0 to 10, with higher scores indicating more severe respiratory distress.

 

The score is based on five parameters, each scored from 0 to 2:

 

1. Nasal Flaring:

  • 0: None
  • 1: Minimal
  • 2: Marked

 

In this case, the infant has marked nasal flaring (score = 2).

 

2. Xiphoid Retractions (Substernal Retractions):

  • 0: None
  • 1: Minimal
  • 2: Distinct

 

The infant has distinct xiphoid retractions (score = 2).

 

3. Intercostal Retractions:

  • 0: None
  • 1: Minimal
  • 2: Marked

 

The infant has minimal intercostal retractions (score = 1).

 

4. Chest Movement (Synchrony of Chest and Abdomen):

  • 0: Synchrony
  • 1: Lag on inspiration
  • 2: See-saw movement

 

The infant has inspiratory lag (score = 1).

 

5. Grunting:

  • 0: None
  • 1: Audible with stethoscope
  • 2: Audible without stethoscope

 

The infant has an audible grunt (score = 2).

 

Calculation:

 

  • Nasal Flaring: 2
  • Xiphoid Retractions: 2
  • Intercostal Retractions: 1
  • Chest Movement: 1
  • Grunting: 2

 

Total Score = 2 + 2 + 1 + 1 + 2 = 8

 

The correct Silverman-Anderson score for this infant would be 8.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Silverman-Anderson score is used to assess the severity of respiratory distress in neonates, with a score of 8 indicating significant distress requiring close monitoring and possibly intervention.

questions.text: What is the most probable diagnosis based on the given image? (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 6th nerve palsy

 

  • The left eye of the patient has limitation of movement laterally.
  • The sixth cranial nerve innervates the lateral rectus. In case of lateral rectus palsy,
    • ÔªøÔªøThere is a convergent squint with limitation of movement outwards, and the face is turned towards the paralysed side.
    • ÔªøÔªøHomonymous diplopia occurs on looking to the paralysed side.
    • ÔªøÔªøThe images are on the same level and erect, becoming more separated on looking more towards the paralysed side.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 3rd cranial nerve palsy:

 

  • Oculomotor nerve supplies all intraocular muscles (sphincter and dilator pupillae) and extraocular muscles (LPS, MR, SR, IR, IO) except lateral rectus and superior oblique.
  • Its paralysis results in
    • Ptosis - Due to the paralysis of LPS
    • Down and out eye (due to unopposed lateral rectus and superior oblique)
    • Loss of accommodation (due to paralysis of ciliary muscle)
    • Loss of light reflex
    • Dilated pupil
    • Crossed diplopia

 

Option C. Bell‚Äôs palsy:

 

  • Bell palsy is the most common cause of peripheral facial palsy.

 

 

Option D. Horner‚Äôs syndrome:

 

  • Sympathetic denervation of face:
    • Ptosis (slight drooping of eyelid: superior tarsal muscle)
    • Miosis (pupil constriction)
    • Anhidrosis (absence of sweating)
    • Flushing of affected side of face

 

Educational Objective:

 

6th nerve palsy is characterized by an inability to abduct the eye, typically presenting as inward turning of the eye due to unopposed medial rectus action, leading to horizontal diplopia that worsens when looking towards the side of the affected nerve. This diagnosis is crucial in patients presenting with lateral gaze limitation following trauma, raised intracranial pressure, or an ischemic event.

questions.text: Which of the following is deficient in a patient with features as shown below?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Tryptophan

 

The Casal collar or Casal necklace is a clinical sign in which there is an erythematous pigmented skin rash in the distribution of a broad collar (dermatomes C3 and C4). It is seen in patients with pellagra, as a result of niacin (vitamin B3) deficiency or tryptophan deficiency.

 

Deficiency of niacin leads to the clinical condition called pellagra. Pellagra is an Italian word, meaning ‚Äúrough skin‚Äù. Pellagra is caused by the deficiency of Tryptophan as well as Niacin. Pellagra is seen more in women; this may be because tryptophan metabolism is inhibited by estrogen metabolites.

 

The symptoms of pellagra are (3 Ds):

 

  1. Dermatitis: In early stages, bright red erythema occurs, especially in the feet, ankles and face. Increased pigmentation around the neck is known as Casal necklace. The dermatitis is precipitated by exposure to sunlight
  2. Diarrhea: The diarrhea may be mild or severe with blood and mucus. This may lead to weight loss. Nausea and vomiting may also be present.
  3. Dementia: It is frequently seen in chronic cases.

 

Delirium is common in acute Pellagra. Irritability, inability to concentrate and poor memory are more common in mild cases. Ataxia, and spasticity are also seen.

 

Other Options:

 

Option.  A. Phenylalanine, C. Glutamine: and D. Arginine: Deficiency of these amino acids are not associated with pellagra.

 

Educational Objective

 

Pellagra can occur due to:

 

  • ÔªøÔªøVitamin B3 (Niacin) deficiency
  • ÔªøÔªøTryptophan deficiency: Niacin is synthetised from tryptophan
  • Deficient synthesis: Kynureninase, an important enzyme in the pathway of tryptophan, is pyridoxal phosphate dependent. So, conversion of tryptophan to niacin is not possible in pyridoxal deficiency.
  • Isoniazid (INH): It is an anti-tubercular drug, which inhibits pyridoxal phosphate formation. Hence, there is block in conversion of tryptophan to NAD.
  • Hartnup disease: Tryptophan absorption from intestine is defective in this congenital disease. Moreover, tryptophan is excreted in urine in large quantities. This leads to lack of tryptophan and consequently deficiency of nicotinamide.
  • Carcinoid syndrome: The tumor utilizes major portion of available tryptophan for synthesis of serotonin; so, tryptophan is unavailable.

questions.text: A patient presents with a 5 cm renal calculus causing severe flank pain. It is detected as a staghorn calculus. What is the best management? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Percutaneous Nephrolithotomy

 

PCNL is the preferred treatment for large and complex kidney stones, especially Staghorn calculi. It involves making a small incision in the patient's back to access the kidney directly. A nephroscope is then used to remove or break up the stone.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. ESWL (Extracorporeal Shock Wave Lithotripsy): ESWL is a non-invasive procedure that uses shock waves to break up kidney stones into smaller pieces, making them easier to pass. While ESWL is effective for smaller kidney stones, it may not be as successful for very large (> 2 cm) and complex Staghorn calculi.

 

Option C. Ureteroscopic removal: Ureteroscopy is a procedure that involves inserting a thin, flexible tube (ureteroscope) through the urethra and bladder to reach the stone in the ureter or renal pelvis. While it can be effective for ureteric stones, it may not be the best choice for Staghorn calculi, especially those larger than 4 cm.

 

Option D. Hydrotherapy: This can be tried for stones up to 5 mm in size. Larger stones would get obstructed in ureter.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Percutaneous Nephrolithotomy (PCNL) is a minimally invasive surgical procedure used to remove large kidney stones. The following are some of the indications for PCNL:

 

  1. Large or complex kidney stones (> 2 cm) or hard stones (Cysteine) that cannot be treated with other minimally invasive procedures such as shock wave lithotripsy (SWL) or ureteroscopy.
  2. Staghorn calculi (large branching stones) that occupy a significant portion of the kidney.
  3. Stones that are associated with renal obstruction or infection.

questions.text: You see these marks on the forearm of a woman who is being constantly harassed for dowry by her in-laws. What is this finding known as?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Hesitation cuts

 

  • The image shows hesitation cuts.
  • It is a series of shallow cuts made by people considering a suicide attempt.
  • These wounds are often multiple, parallel, non-lethal cuts.
  • The throat, and wrist are the most common sites.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Grazed abrasion: Grazed abrasions occur when the skin is rubbed or scraped against a rough surface, leading to the removal of the superficial layers of the skin. This does not match the image shown, which depicts clean, linear cuts.

 

Option C. Laceration: Lacerations are deeper tears or cuts in the skin caused by blunt trauma. They are typically irregular and have abraded edges. The image shows clean, linear cuts, not consistent with lacerations.

 

Option D. Patterned bruise: Patterned bruises are caused by an object leaving a distinct pattern on the skin, such as from a belt or other implement. The marks in the image are linear and clean, not consistent with the diffuse and patterned nature of bruises.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hesitation cuts are superficial, parallel, and multiple cuts typically found in accessible areas like the wrist or throat, often indicating a cry for help or a practice attempt by individuals contemplating suicide.

choices.text: Area under the curve

questions.text: The extent of drug absorption in plasma concentration vs time graph is represented by:(INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Area under the curve

 

Area under the curve (AUC) is a measure of the total drug exposure in the bloodstream over time. It reflects the total amount of drug absorbed and is often used to assess the overall bioavailability of a drug. AUC is crucial for determining the efficacy and safety of a medication.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tmax (Time to Maximum Concentration): Tmax represents the time it takes for a drug to reach its maximum concentration (Cmax) in the bloodstream. It tells about rate of drug absorption.

 

Option C. Cmax (Maximum Concentration): Cmax represents the highest concentration of a drug in the bloodstream after administration. This parameter is important because it indicates the peak therapeutic effect and helps assess the risk of side effects associated with high drug concentrations.

 

Option D. t1/2 (Half-Life): t1/2 is the time it takes for half of the drug to be eliminated from the bloodstream. It is not directly related to drug absorption but is essential in understanding how long a drug remains in the body and how often it needs to be administered.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Area Under the Curve (AUC) in a plasma concentration vs. time graph represents the extent of drug absorption, reflecting the total drug exposure over time and the overall bioavailability of the drug.

questions.text: All of the following are the contents of the carotid sheath except?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Sympathetic chain

 

Explanation:

 

The carotid sheath's content is not the sympathetic chain. It is located in the neck, behind the carotid sheath and in front of the transverse processes of the cervical vertebrae.

 

The carotid sheath is a layer of loose connective tissue formed by adjacent portions of the investing layer of deep cervical fascia, the pretracheal fascia, and the prevertebral fascia.

 

Contents of carotid sheath:

 

  • Common and internal carotid arteries
  • Internal jugular vein
  • Vagus nerve (10th Cranial nerve)
  • Ansa cervicalis

 

Note: The glossopharyngeal, accessory, and hypoglossal nerves are located in the carotid sheath's upper portion.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Carotid artery: The common carotid artery and its internal branch (the internal carotid artery) are primary contents of the carotid sheath. In the neck, the common carotid bifurcates into the internal and external carotid arteries. Only the internal carotid artery continues to ascend within the carotid sheath.

 

Option C. Internal jugular vein: The internal jugular vein is a major vein in the neck that drains the brain, face, and much of the neck. It runs in close proximity to the internal and common carotid arteries and is another primary content of the carotid sheath.

 

Option D. 10th cranial nerve, which is also known as Vagus nerve. It is present in carotid sheath medial to internal jugular vein and lateral to internal carotid artery. It is a mixed nerve.It descends from the skull base through the jugular foramen and is present in the carotid sheath. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The sympathetic chain (sympathetic trunk) is a bilateral series of ganglia that run vertically alongside the vertebral column. It is involved in the autonomic sympathetic innervation of the body. Importantly, the sympathetic chain itself is not contained within the carotid sheath. However, sympathetic fibers that come from the chain (e.g., the carotid plexus) do accompany structures within the sheath, especially the internal and common carotid arteries.

questions.text: Infertility in Kartagener's syndrome is due to which of the following? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Asthenospermia

 

Asthenospermia (Immotile sperm [Greek sthenos = strength]

 

Kartagener result from loss of function of axonemal dynein that impairs sperm motility. Respiratory Ciliary dysmotility leads to bronchiectasis and recurrent infections. Association of situs inversus is noted.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Oligospermia: Incorrect because while sperm count can be affected in some genetic or hormonal disorders, in Kartagener's syndrome, the sperm count is typically normal; the issue lies in their motility.

 

Option C. Epididymis obstruction: Incorrect as this is not a feature of Kartagener‚Äôs syndrome. While structural anomalies in the reproductive tract can lead to such issues, Kartagener‚Äôs syndrome specifically affects the motility of sperm due to ciliary dysfunction.

 

Option D. Undescended testes: Incorrect as undescended testes are not associated with Kartagener‚Äôs syndrome, which primarily affects ciliary function and not the anatomical position of the testes.

 

Educational Objective:
 

Infertility in Kartagener's syndrome is primarily due to asthenospermia, which is caused by the immobility of sperm. This immotility results from the genetic defect affecting the dynein arm of sperm flagella, similar to the defect affecting cilia in the respiratory tract, leading to the classic symptoms of the syndrome.

 

Reference - Harrison/Pulmonology/Bronchiectasis/Chapter 290

questions.text: What is the antigen present in the recombinant HPV vaccine?  (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) L1

 

Explanation:

 

The recombinant HPV vaccine primarily includes the L1 protein, which self-assembles into virus-like particles, providing the basis for immune recognition without causing the disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. E1 + E2: E1 and E2 are early viral proteins, not included in vaccines due to their role in viral replication.

 

Option B. E6 + E7: E6 and E7 are proteins involved in oncogenesis, not appropriate for vaccine development.

 

Option D. L2: L2 is also a capsid protein but not the primary antigen used in current HPV vaccines.

 

Educational objective:

 

The L1 protein of HPV forms the basis of the recombinant HPV vaccine, effectively stimulating an immune response by mimicking the virus structure.

questions.text: Which of the following is not included in the quadruple screening test?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Inhibin B

 

Inhibin B is not included in the quadruple screening test. The quadruple test, typically performed in the second trimester between 15-21 weeks of gestation, includes Maternal Serum AFP, hCG, Unconjugated Estriol, and Dimeric Inhibin A, not Inhibin B.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Unconjugated Estriol (E3): This hormone is included in the quadruple screening test. It helps in assessing the risk of certain chromosomal conditions such as Down syndrome.

 

Option C. AFP: Alpha-fetoprotein is a key component of the quadruple screening test, used primarily to screen for neural tube defects and abdominal wall defects.

 

Option D. hCG: Human chorionic gonadotropin is also a part of the quadruple screening, important for evaluating the risk of chromosomal abnormalities.

 

Educational Objective:
