The take-home point for students is to accurately identify the components of the quadruple screening test, which are AFP, hCG, Unconjugated Estriol, and Dimeric Inhibin A. It‚Äôs essential to distinguish between Dimeric Inhibin A and Inhibin B, as only the former is included in the test, reflecting a specific protocol used in prenatal screening for chromosomal abnormalities.

choices.text: The quantity of sperms
The motility of sperms
The morphology of sperms
The number of sperm

questions.text: Identify the best parameter to assess in case of male infertility? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) The morphology of sperms

 

Explanation:

 

The morphology of sperms is considered the best parameter to assess male infertility. Sperm morphology refers to the size and shape of sperm, and abnormalities in these characteristics can significantly affect a man's fertility.

 

Key Points:

 

  • Sperm Morphology: Characterization of normal sperm morphology shows improved correlation with fertilization rates during IVF cycles. A significantly decreased fertilization rate is observed when the normal morphology of the sample falls below the strict criteria of 4%.
  • Sperm Quantity and Number: While the quantity and number of sperms are important, they are not as critical as morphology in determining fertility potential.
  • Sperm Motility: Motility is also a crucial factor, but morphology has a stronger correlation with fertilization success.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The quantity of sperms: Refers to the total volume of ejaculate, which is less indicative of fertility compared to morphology.

 

Option B. The motility of sperms: Important for fertility but not as strongly correlated with fertilization success as morphology.

 

Option D. The number of sperm: Similar to the quantity, the number is important but does not correlate as closely with fertilization rates as morphology does.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sperm morphology is the most significant parameter for assessing male infertility, as it closely correlates with fertilization rates during assisted reproductive techniques like IVF.

questions.text:
Which of the following are the classical markers of a seminoma: (INICET NOV 2023)

 

  1. KIT    
  2. OCT 3
  3. PLAP
  4. HCG
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1, 2 and 3

 

The classical markers of a seminoma include KIT (CD117), OCT 3 (also known as OCT3/4), and PLAP (Placental Alkaline Phosphatase). These markers are commonly used in the diagnosis and characterization of seminomas due to their high specificity.

 

1. KIT (CD117): A receptor tyrosine kinase that is strongly expressed in seminomas, aiding in differentiation from other testicular neoplasms.

 

2. OCT 3 (OCT3/4): A transcription factor essential for maintaining the pluripotency of germ cells and expressed in seminomas, reflecting their embryonal origin.

 

3. PLAP (Placental Alkaline Phosphatase): Frequently elevated in seminomas, this enzyme helps in confirming the germ cell origin of the tumor.

 

Other Options:

 

4. HCG (Human Chorionic Gonadotropin): Although some seminomas may express low levels of HCG, it is not considered a classical marker like the others, being more indicative of non-seminomatous germ cell tumors.

 

HCG may be present in ~15‚Äì20% of seminomas. However it is a classical marker for Choriocarcinoma (produced by syncytiotrophoblastic cells)

 

Therefore, some seminomas can elevate serum hCG

 

However:

 

  • Not seen in all seminoma
  • More characteristic of choriocarcinoma and mixed germ cell tumors

 

Educational objective:

 

When diagnosing seminoma, clinicians should primarily focus on markers KIT, OCT3/4, and PLAP due to their high specificity and relevance to the germ cell lineage. HCG, although sometimes present, is not a classical marker for seminoma.

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl arrives with several swellings and numerous brown rashes. Bone scans reveal heightened activity in the femur, skull, and rib areas. There are irregularities in her biochemical values. Additionally, she has a past medical record of hypothyroidism. The provided image displays an X-ray of her femur. What is the probable diagnosis from the options provided?(INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. McCune-Albright syndrome

 

MCCUNE ALBRIGHT SYNDROME

 

  • Polyostotic fibrous dysplasia (multiple bones involved)
  • Precocious puberty (endocrine abnormalities)
  • Cutaneous Pigmentation (caf√© Au lait: coffee-colored spots)
  • The cafe au lait spots have characteristically irregular ragged borders (commonly called ‚Äúcoast of Maine‚Äù bor- ders), as opposed to the smoothly marginated borders (‚Äúcoast of California‚Äù) of the spots seen in neurofibromatosis.
  • Surgical treatment by curettage + bone grafting is indicated when significant deformity or pathological fracture occurs or when significant pain exists.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Langerhans cell histiocytosis. It is the idiopathic destruction of histiocytes. The disease has characteristics of both an abnormal reactive process and a neoplastic process. It may present initially as a rash, and can disseminate and involve bone marrow, lungs, liver, spleen, lymph nodes, gastrointestinal (GI) tract, and the pituitary gland. Histologically, the primary lesion is granulomatous with an influx of eosinophils, macrophages, T cells and multinucleated cells. The Birbeck granule is the microscopic hallmark of the disorder but may not be seen in lesions of the spleen, liver, and GI tract. The rash may be distinguished by the presence of petechiae, bloody crusting, or firmly indurated nodules. Bony involvement occurs in 78% patients. Solitary osseous lesions are incidentally found and may include the skull, hip/pelvis, femur, or ribs. This bony involvement may produce bone pain. In long bones, endosteal scalloping may be responsible for a ‚Äúbudding appearance‚Äù.

 

 

Endosteal scalloping presenting as budding appearance

 

Option C. Neuroma with bone involvement. Morton's neuroma is one of the most common pain syndromes affecting the forefoot. It is characterized by tenderness and burning pain in the plantar surface of the forefoot, with painful paresthesias in the two affected toes. This pain syndrome is caused by perineural fibrosis of the interdigital nerves. Although the nerves between the third and fourth toes are affected most commonly, the second and third toes and, rarely, the fourth and fifth toes can be affected as well. Patients may feel like they are walking with a stone in the shoe. The pain worsens with prolonged standing or walking for long distances and is exacerbated by poorly fitting or improperly padded shoes. Morton's neuroma is associated with wearing tight, narrow-toed shoes. On physical examination, pain can be reproduced by firmly squeezing the 2 metatarsal heads together with one hand while placing firm pressure on the interdigital space with the other hand. This maneuver is known as the Mulder sign. The patient exhibits an antalgic gait in an effort to reduce weight bearing during walking.

 

 

Option D. Papillary carcinoma of thyroid. Papillary thyroid carcinoma (PTC) is an epithelial malignancy showing follicular cell differentiation and nuclear features. It is the most frequent thyroid neoplasm. The tumor usually appears as an irregular solid mass. One key feature is the ability to invade adjacent structures like lymphatics. About 10% patients may present with metastatic disease at initial presentation. It usually presents as an asymptomatic thyroid mass with or without enlargement of regional (cervical) lymph nodes. Hoarseness and dysphagia occur in approximately 20% cases, signaling recurrent laryngeal nerve involvement with vocal cord paralysis or tracheal compression. Nodal metastases in the lateral neck are reported in 27% patients. The examination reveals a painless hard lesion of less than 5 cm. The mass is often fixed and has irregular borders.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The presentation of several swellings and numerous brown rashes represents caf√© Au lait spots.
  • Bone scans reveal heightened activity in the femur, skull, and rib areas.
  • There are irregularities in her biochemical values.
  • Presence of past medical history of hypothyroidism, and Shepherd crook deformity of femur in the given image, all point towards the McCune Albright Syndrome.

questions.text: Which of the following will halter the maturity of collagen?(INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Scurvy

 

Option B. Scurvy:

  • Scurvy is a nutritional deficiency disease caused by a lack of vitamin C (ascorbic acid).
  • Vitamin C is essential for the synthesis of collagen. Without adequate vitamin C, collagen production is impaired, leading to the characteristic symptoms of scurvy, including impaired wound healing and gum bleeding.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Beri-Beri:

  • Beri-Beri is a nutritional deficiency disease caused by a lack of vitamin B1 (thiamine).
  • Thiamine deficiency primarily affects the nervous system and cardiovascular system and does not directly impact collagen maturity.

 

Option C. Night Blindness:

  • Night blindness is often associated with a deficiency in vitamin A (retinol).
  • Vitamin A deficiency primarily affects vision and does not directly impact collagen maturity.

 

Option D. Rickets:

  • Rickets is a nutritional deficiency disease caused by a lack of vitamin D, calcium, or phosphate.
  • Vitamin D plays a role in calcium and phosphate homeostasis, which is crucial for bone health but does not directly impact collagen maturity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Scurvy is the condition that will halt the maturity of collagen because it is caused by a deficiency in vitamin C, which is essential for collagen synthesis.

 

Ascorbic acid is necessary for the post-translational hydroxylation of proline and lysine residues.

 

 

Hydroxyproline and hydroxylysine are essential for the formation of cross links in the collagen, which gives the tensile strength to the fibers. This process is absolutely necessary for the normal production of supporting tissues such as osteoid, collagen and intercellular cement substance of capillaries.

 

Thus, in ascorbic acid deficiency (Scurvy), collagen is abnormal and the intercellular cement substance is brittle. So, capillaries are fragile, leading to the tendency to bleed even under minor pressure.

questions.text: A patient diagnosed with tuberculosis is learning about available government support for nutritional aid during treatment. Which of the following accurately represents a feature of the Nikshay Poshan Yojana? [AIIMS MAY 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) ‚Çπ 500 is given per month

 

  • Nikshay Poshan Yojana provides nutritional support in the form of money to patients of TB.
  • Patients receive ‚Çπ 500 per month under this scheme.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nikshay Poshan Yojana:

 

  • Financial incentive of Rs 500/- per month for each notified TB patient for duration for which the patient is on anti-TB treatment
  • All TB patients notified on or after 1st April 2018 including all existing TB patients under treatment are eligible to receive incentive

questions.text: Basophils are activated by? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) IL-5

 

The best answer for basophil differentiation of basophil is IL3 however considering the options given for this particular question in INICET exam the appropriate answer shall be IL-5

 

Interleukin-5 (IL-5) is a cytokine that specifically acts on eosinophils and basophils. It plays a crucial role in their growth, differentiation, activation, and survival. In the case of basophils, IL-5 stimulates their activation, leading to the release of histamine and other mediators that are involved in allergic responses and inflammation.

 

IL-5: Primarily activates eosinophilia but also involved in basophil growth and differentiation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. INF-gamma: Interferon-gamma is primarily involved in the activation of macrophages and is a key cytokine in the Th1 immune response, but it does not specifically activate basophils.

 

Option C. TNF-alpha: Tumor Necrosis Factor-alpha is a pro-inflammatory cytokine involved in systemic inflammation and is a major mediator in the acute phase reaction, but it does not specifically activate basophils.

 

Option D. IL-2: Interleukin-2 is crucial for the growth, proliferation, and differentiation of T cells and natural killer (NK) cells, but it does not play a significant role in the activation of basophils.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Interleukins are a type of cytokine, which are small proteins produced by immune cells that play a crucial role in regulating the immune response.

 

A brief overview of some of the key interleukins and their functions:

 

  1. Interleukin-1 (IL-1): This interleukin is involved in the regulation of inflammation and immune responses, as well as activation of immune cells such as T cells and B cells.
  2. Interleukin-2 (IL-2): This cytokine is primarily produced by T cells and plays a key role in the activation and proliferation of T cells and natural killer (NK) cells. It is also involved in the differentiation of immune cells, such as the development of memory T cells.
  3. Interleukin-4 (IL-4): Plays a key role in the development of Th2 cells, which are involved in the immune response to parasites and allergies. IL-4 also stimulates the production of antibodies by B cells.
  4. Interleukin-5 (IL-5): Primarily activates eosinophils but also involved in basophil growth and differentiation, contributing to their role in allergic responses and inflammation.
  5. Interleukin-6 (IL-6): Plays a key role in the regulation of inflammation and immune responses. It can stimulate the production of acute-phase proteins, such as C-reactive protein, as well as the activation of immune cells like plasma cells.
  6. Interleukin-10 (IL-10): Plays a key role in regulating the immune response and limiting inflammation. It can suppress the production of pro-inflammatory cytokines, as well as the activation of immune cells.
  7. Interleukin-12 (IL-12): IL-12 is involved in the activation of T cells and NK cells. It can stimulate the differentiation of Th1 cells, which are involved in the immune response to intracellular pathogens.

 

Ref: Wintrobe‚Äôs Clinical hematology, 14th edition

questions.text: Which of the following amino acids is not formed after post-translational modification? (AIIMS May 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Selenocysteine

 

Selenocysteine is abbreviated as SeCys is the 21st human amino acid.

It is formed by co-translational modification.

 

It is seen at the active site of the following enzymes:

 

  1. Thioredoxin reductase
  2. Glutathione peroxidase, which scavenges peroxides;
  3. De-iodinase that removes iodine from thyroxine to make triiodothyronine
  4. Selenoprotein P, a glycoprotein seen in mammalian blood.

 

Replacement of Secys by Cys will lead to decreased activity of these enzymes.

Deficiency of these enzymes may be related with atherosclerosis, as these enzymes have an antioxidant function. Their concentration falls in selenium deficiency.

 

Its structure is COOH‚ÄìCHNH2‚ÄìCH2‚ÄìSeH. It is incorporated into protein during translation process. There is a tRNA, specific to carry Secys. The codon is UGA. Biosynthesis of selenocysteine is by replacing the oxygen of serine by selenium; this is done by two steps:

 

  1. Se + ATP ‚Üí Se-P + AMP + Pi
  2. Serine + Se-P ‚Üí SeCys + Pi

 

The code for SeCys is UGA, which is identified by a SeCys insertion element in the mRNA, with the help of a specific elongation factor. The tRNA-Sec is first charged with serine, then it is converted into SeCys. This is then inserted into the correct position, when protein is synthesized.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Triiodothyronine (T3): Formed by post-translational modification of thyroxine (T4) through the enzymatic removal of an iodine atom.

 

Option C. Hydroxyproline: Formed by post-translational hydroxylation of proline, a process critical for the stability of collagen.

 

Option D. Hydroxylysine: Formed by post-translational hydroxylation of lysine, also important in collagen stability.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text:
Which of these options are considered direct gonioscopes?(INICET May 2023)

 

  1. Goldmann
  2. Richardson
  3. Zeis
  4. Koeppe
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 2, 4

 

Richardson and Koeppe are direct gonioscopes.

 

DIRECT GONIOSCOPY - It is performed with a steep convex lens which permits light from the angle to exit the eye closer to the perpendicular at the lens - air interface. These lenses are used with an operating microscope.

 

DIRECT GONIOSCOPE IMAGE

 

 

Examples ‚Äì

 

  • Koeppe goniolens
  • Richardson- Shaffer's lens
  • Sieback goniolens
  • Worth goniolens
  • Swan Jacob's lens
  • Huskins barkan's lens

 

INDIRECT GONIOSCOPY - uses mirrors or prism to overcome the problem of total internal reflection. Moreover, it uses the slit lamp's illumination and magnification system to its advantage.

 

INDIRECT GONIOSCOPE IMAGE

 

 

Examples ‚Äì

 

  • Goldmann Gonioprism
  • Zeis Gonioprism
  • Tokel Gonioprism

 

Educational Objective:

 

Direct gonioscopes like Richardson and Koeppe provide a detailed and direct view of the anterior chamber angle, which is valuable in diagnostic and certain therapeutic procedures.

questions.text: In the fracture seen in the X-ray below, what is the most commonly expected vascular injury?(AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Brachial artery

 

  • The given image shows the supracondylar fracture of the humerus.
  • Fracture supracondylar humerus is:
    • Most common fracture associated with vascular injury.
    • Most common fracture to involve brachial artery (10% cases).
    • Most common cause of volkmann's ischemia and compartment syndrome in children.
    • Most common cause of volkmann's ischemic contracture.
    • Non-union is unknown.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Radial artery. It can be associated with the fracture of the distal radius.

 

Option C. Ulnar artery. It can be associated with the comminuted fracture of the distal radius.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The given image shows the supracondylar humerus fracture which is mostly associated with the brachial artery injury.

questions.text: Which among the following is wrong about DIC? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Increased fibrinogen

 

Disseminated Intravascular Coagulation (DIC) is a complex condition characterized by systemic activation of blood clotting, which results in the generation and deposition of fibrin, leading to microvascular thrombi in various organs and contributing to multiple organ dysfunction syndrome. As a part of this process, there is widespread consumption of clotting factors and platelets, which leads to a paradoxical increase in bleeding risk.

 

  • Increased fibrinogen is incorrect because in DIC, fibrinogen is typically decreased, not increased. This decrease is due to its consumption during the formation of fibrin clots throughout the body.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 30% of patients w/DIC may have schistocytes on PS.

 

Option B. Consumption of clotting factors leads to ‚ÜëPT, aPTT. Presence of normal PT, aPTT w/schistocytes hints towards possibility of MAHA.

 

Option D. FDP are elevated due to activation of coagulation cascade.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In DIC, one typically sees a constellation of laboratory findings including decreased fibrinogen, increased PT and aPTT, elevated FDPs, and the presence of schistocytes on peripheral blood smear. These changes reflect both the excessive activation of the coagulation cascade and the secondary activation of fibrinolytic pathways, leading to the consumption of clotting factors and secondary bleeding complications.

 

Reference - Harrison/Hematology/Coagulation disorders

questions.text: A 56-year-old woman was admitted to a tertiary care hospital in New Delhi following a fall at home. During her stay, the nursing staff consistently followed protocols for waste segregation. Based on the guidelines for biomedical waste management, which type of waste should be correctly disposed of in the following mentioned bag? [AIIMS MAY 2017]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Urine Bag

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Anatomical waste: Anatomical wastes is disposed in yellow bin.

 

Option C. Soiled waste: Soiled wastes are disposed in yellow bin.

 

Option D. Sharp waste: Sharp wastes are disposed in white puncture proof, leak-proof, tamper-proof white containers.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The red biohazard bag is used for the disposal of Contaminated plastic recyclable waste like tubing, bottles, intravenous tubes and sets, catheters, urine bags, syringes (without needles) and gloves

questions.text:
What diseases' risk is elevated due to smoking? (INICET MAY 2023)

 

  1. Duct ectasia
  2. Fibroadenoma
  3. Mondor's disease
  4. Breast carcinoma
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1, 3, 4

 

Cigarette smoking elevates the likelihood of experiencing duct ectasia, Mondor's disease, and breast carcinoma.

 

1. Duct ectasia: Typically seen in smokers. Patient presents with greenish Nipple discharge and Lump in breast with nipple retraction. Management is done by Conical excision of ductal system - Hadfield procedure.

 

3. Mondor's disease: Superficial thrombophlebitis of veins of breast / chest wall or axilla ‚Äì males. Patient presents with cord like, thick, tender initially. Most common vein involves lateral thoracic vein. Smoking was identified as a possible contributing element in the development of Mondor's disease.

 

4. Breast carcinoma: Risk factors involve Age > 60, Early menarche (< 12 years), late menopause (>55 years), nulli-parity, late age of first child birth, Hormone replacement therapy, Inadequate breast feeding (breast feeding for > 12 months reduces risk), Alcohol & smoking consumption, obesity, Prior chest wall radiation, Family history.

 

Other Option:

 

2. Fibroadenoma: Tumor of breast arising from ductal epithelium or fibrous elements or both. It has two components ‚Äì fibrous or stromal elements + glandular elements. Patient presents with slow growing lump (2-3cm), mobile like a mouse in breast. Smoking is not a risk factor for fibroadenomas.

questions.text: A patient is undergoing modified radical neck dissection (MRND) for laryngeal malignancy. While ligating the internal jugular vein, his ETCO2 dropped from 40 mmHg to 14 mmHg, and the patient developed hypotension along with cardiac arrhythmia. Which of the following is the most likely cause? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Venous air embolism

 

Explanation:

 

Venous Air Embolism:

 

  • Definition: It refers to the entry of air into the venous system, which can then travel to the heart and block the pulmonary circulation.
  • Presentation: A sudden drop in ETCO2, hypotension, and potential cardiac arrhythmias. A "mill wheel" murmur might be heard on auscultation.
  • Relevance to the Scenario: The sudden drop in ETCO2, combined with hypotension and cardiac arrhythmia following manipulation of the internal jugular vein during surgery in a head-up position, strongly suggests venous air embolism.

 

There are four important events here:

  1. Bleeding from the internal jugular vein (severed vein which can entrap air)
  2. A drastic fall in ETCO2
  3. Hypotension
  4. Neck surgery ‚Äì requires head-up position which reduces blood pressure in neck veins

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sympathetic Overactivity:

  • Definition: It refers to excessive stimulation of the sympathetic nervous system.
  • Presentation: It typically manifests as hypertension (raised blood pressure) and tachycardia (increased heart rate).
  • Relevance to the Scenario: The patient developed hypotension, not hypertension, so this option is less likely.

 

Option B. Vagal Stimulation:

  • Definition: Activation of the vagus nerve, one of the cranial nerves, which plays a role in controlling the heart, lungs, and digestive tract.
  • Presentation: Vagal stimulation can cause bradycardia (slowed heart rate) and hypotension.
  • Relevance to the Scenario: While vagal stimulation can explain the hypotension and arrhythmia, it does not account for the drastic drop in ETCO2.

 

Option D. Carotid Body Stimulation:

  • Definition: The carotid body is a small cluster of chemoreceptors located at the bifurcation of the carotid artery. It monitors changes in blood oxygen levels.
  • Presentation: Stimulation can cause changes in heart rate and blood pressure, but it typically results in hypertension.
  • Relevance to the Scenario: Given that the patient is hypotensive, this option is less likely.

 

Educational Objective :

 

  • A sudden drop in ETCO2, hypotension, and cardiac arrhythmias during surgery, especially involving the internal jugular vein and head-up positioning, strongly suggests venous air embolism.

 

Ref: Miller‚Äôs Anesthesia, 9th Ed. Pgs 1878-1880

choices.text: Procedure can be done in both lateral & prone position
Diagnosing an infiltrative or granulomatous disease

questions.text: Which of the following is not true regarding the procedure done using the instrument given in the image below? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Contraindicated if platelet count <40,000

 

The image shows a bone marrow biopsy needle. Thrombocytopenia is not a contraindication, and platelet transfusion can be performed if clinically warranted prior to the procedure, commonly performed if platelet counts are below 20,000 cells/microliter.

 

 

Indications of bone marrow biopsy:

 

  • Evaluation of unexplained anemia, leukopenia, thrombocytopenia, pancytopenia
  • Evaluation of polycythemia, thrombocytosis, leukocytosis
  • Diagnosis and staging of lymphoma or solid tumors
  • Diagnosis and evaluation of plasma cell disorders and leukemias
  • Evaluation of suspected infiltrative and storage diseases
  • Evaluation of fever of unknown origin, suspected mycobacterial, fungal, or parasitic infections, or granulomatous diseases

 

Contraindications of bone marrow biopsy:

 

  • Severe hemophilia
  • Severe disseminated intravascular coagulopathy
  • Severe bleeding disorders

 

Procedure for bone marrow biopsy:

 

Prone or lateral position is chosen for the procedure. Posterior superior iliac spine is identified. After disinfection and local anesthesia, the patient is asked to inhale slowly through the nose and exhale slowly through the mouth to relieve anxiety. The needle is inserted and rotated on its axis.

 

On reaching the desired depth, the stylet is removed and needle is advanced. The needle is rotated in the opposite direction to loosen the specimen. It is then withdrawn using the same rotational movement.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Breath holding is required: This is true for minimizing patient movement during the procedure.

 

Option C. Procedure can be done in both lateral & prone position: This is true and allows for flexibility depending on the patient's condition and biopsy site.

 

Option D. Diagnosing an infiltrative or granulomatous disease: This is true and one of the key indications for bone marrow biopsy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A platelet count of <40,000 is not an absolute contraindication for bone marrow biopsy, as platelet transfusion can be performed to mitigate bleeding risk.

 

Source - https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK559232/

questions.text: An experiment is being conducted on a dog blood pressure to study the effect of acetylcholine. The blood pressure is recorded at each intervention and is shown below. What does phase 4 in the graph indicate? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Nicotinic action of acetylcholine

 

For demonstrating nicotinic actions (on ganglia) of acetylcholine, two criteria are required:

 

  • High dose of acetylcholine (around 5 mg).
  • Muscarinic receptors must be blocked by giving atropine (to avoid death of the animal due to overactivity of muscarinic receptors)

 

About the given graph:

 

 

  • In phases 1 and 2, Acetylcholine is given at doses of 2 mcg and 50 mcg. This leads to a drop in the BP due to its action in the muscarinic receptors.
  • In phase 3 when its muscarinic action is blocked by atropine, administration of 50 mcg of Acetylcholine does not cause a fall in BP.
  • But in phase 4, when Ach is administered at higher dose of 5 mg, it acts on the Neuronal Nicotinic receptors located in CNS, ganglia and adrenals, leading to their stimulation and release of norepinephrine, which causes the BP to shoot up. Thus, Phase 4 in the graph indicates the nicotinic action of acetylcholine at higher doses.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Muscarinic action of acetylcholine: Muscarinic actions are demonstrated in Phases 1 and 2, where acetylcholine causes a drop in blood pressure. This option is incorrect for Phase 4.

 

Option B. Potentiation of acetylcholine: Potentiation would suggest an increased effect due to repeated or combined actions, which is not the primary mechanism demonstrated in Phase 4.

 

Option C. Antagonism of acetylcholine: Antagonism would imply inhibition of acetylcholine’s effects. Phase 3 demonstrates antagonism (by atropine) but not Phase 4.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Phase 4 in the graph indicates the nicotinic action of acetylcholine, characterized by a rise in blood pressure due to the stimulation of neuronal nicotinic receptors after administering a high dose of acetylcholine (5 mg) following the blockade of muscarinic receptors with atropine.

questions.text: What does the following image show? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Emperipolesis

 

The image shows the phenomenon of emperipolesis. Here, intact hematopoietic cells are seen within the cytoplasm of the host cell without any damage. In this case, a band neutrophil is seen inside a megakaryocyte.

 

A rare biological phenomenon called emperipolesis involves a cell penetrating another live cell. In emperipolesis, as opposed to phagocytosis, when the enveloped cell is destroyed by the macrophage's lysosomal enzymes, the cell can exit at any time without causing any structural or functional problems for either of them. This process can be either physiological or pathological. Histiocytes and Megakaryocytes generally participate in peripolesis. It is seen in Rosai-Dorfman disease and Hodgkin's disease are pathological circumstances when this process is observed.

 

NOTE:

 

Emperipolesis vs Entosis:

 

Emperipolesis is a cellular process in which one cell enters into another cell without being degraded or destroyed. This process occurs in various cell types, including immune cells and cancer cells, and is thought to play a role in cell-to-cell communication and immune surveillance. In emperipolesis, the engulfed cell remains intact and is usually released from the host cell after a certain period of time.

 

Entosis, on the other hand, is a cellular process in which one cell actively engulfs and digests another cell. This process occurs primarily in epithelial cells and is thought to play a role in tissue homeostasis and elimination of damaged or excess cells. In Entosis, the engulfed cell is degraded and digested by the host cell's lysosomes.

 

In summary, the main difference between emperipolesis and Entosis is that in emperipolesis, the engulfed cell remains intact and is usually released from the host cell, while in Entosis, the engulfed cell is degraded and digested by the host cell.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Autophagy: This process involves the degradation of a cell's own components through the lysosomal machinery.

 

Option C. Phagocytosis: The process by which a cell engulfs and digests foreign particles or cells, typically leading to the degradation of the engulfed material.

 

Option D. Amoebic autophagy: Not a recognized term; may be confused with autophagy or phagocytosis processes seen in amoebas.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Emperipolesis is a unique process where one cell enters another without being destroyed, differentiating it from phagocytosis and entosis, with the host cell usually being a megakaryocyte or histiocyte.

questions.text: The stroke volume depends on end-diastolic volume. This is best represented as?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Length-tension relationship

 

The relationship between end-diastolic volume and stroke volume is best represented by length-tension relationship.

 

Frank-Starling mechanism states that the greater the heart muscle is stretched during filling, the greater is the force of contraction and the greater the quantity of blood pumped into the aorta or, stated another way: Within physiologic limits, the heart pumps all the blood that returns to it by the way of the veins.

 

When an extra amount of blood flows into the ventricles, the cardiac muscle itself is stretched to greater length. This in turn causes the muscle to contract with increased force because the actin and myosin filaments are brought to a more nearly optimal degree of overlap for force generation. Therefore, the ventricle, because of its increased pumping, automatically pumps the extra blood into the arteries.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The relationship between end-diastolic volume and stroke volume in the heart is best described by the length-tension relationship, which underlies the Frank-Starling mechanism. This principle explains how increased filling of the heart leads to greater contraction force and increased stroke volume.

choices.text: The patient would need another point-of-care diagnostic test for the same clinical condition.
Prevalence of the disease is 2%.
Patient is less likely to have the disease.
Patient has been wrongly ruled out due to false negativity.

questions.text: A point-of-care diagnostic test with a sensitivity of 98% shows a negative test result in a patient. What does this imply? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Patient is less likely to have the disease.

 

A negative result in a diagnostic test with a sensitivity of 98% implies that the patient is less likely to have the disease.

 

Sensitivity is the proportion of all people with the disease who test positive. It is the probability that the test will be positive when the disease is present. The sensitivity of a test is determined by how many patients with the disease actually test positive (true positives) out of the total number of diseased individuals. In this case, a sensitivity of 98% means that 98% of people with the disease would test positive, so a negative result would likely indicate that the patient does not have the disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The patient would not need another point-of-care diagnostic test for the same clinical condition because the sensitivity of the diagnostic test is 98%.

 

Option B. Prevalence refers to the number of old and new cases at a given point in time or over a period of time in a given population. It cannot be derived from the given data.

 

Option D. The higher the sensitivity of a diagnostic test, the lower will be the number of false negatives. Since the test has a 98% sensitivity, the patient most likely does not have the disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The higher the sensitivity of a diagnostic test, the fewer false negatives occur, meaning a negative result implies the patient is less likely to have the disease.

questions.text: Identify the organism given in the image below? (INICET MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Balantidium coli

 

The given image is the trophozoite form of the Balantidium coli.

 

Balantidium coli occurs in two stages

 

  • Trophozoites are oval in shape and contain two nuclei. There is the presence of cilia over the entire surface and are larger around the mouth. Its anterior end is narrow and the posterior end is broad. At the anterior end, there is a groove leading to the mouth (cytostome). Posteriorly, there is a small anal pore (cytopyge).
  • Cysts are smaller, round with a micronucleus, a macronucleus and many contractile vacuoles.

 

Living trophozoites/cysts are yellowish or greenish in color on wet mount.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Entamoeba dispar: Entamoeba dispar is morphologically identical to Entamoeba histolytica but non-pathogenic. It does not have the characteristic cilia and shape seen in Balantidium coli.

 

Option C. Cryptosporidium: Cryptosporidium species are small protozoans that cause cryptosporidiosis. They appear as small, round oocysts and do not have cilia.

 

Option D. Giardia: Giardia lamblia is a flagellated protozoan that causes giardiasis. Its trophozoites have a distinctive pear shape with flagella and two nuclei that resemble "eyes."

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Balantidium coli is characterized by its oval shape, presence of cilia, and distinct anterior and posterior ends in the trophozoite form. The trophozoite stage contains two nuclei and is motile, while the cyst stage is smaller and round, aiding in transmission and infection.

questions.text: A 34-year-old man with hypertension is diagnosed with stage 4 chronic kidney disease, with eGFR of <30. His doctor wants to prescribe a thiazide diuretic. Which of the following can be given? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Metolazone

 

In the context of a patient with stage 4 chronic kidney disease (CKD) and an estimated glomerular filtration rate (eGFR) of less than 30 mL/min, the choice of diuretic is important, as not all diuretics are effective in patients with significantly reduced kidney function. Among the thiazides, metolazone remains effective in presence of severe renal failure whereas traditional thiazides like chlorthalidone, hydrochlorothiazide and chlorthiazide are ineffective.

 

The reason Metolazone remains effective in patients with advanced chronic kidney disease (CKD), where traditional thiazide diuretics are less effective, lies in their pharmacokinetic properties and the way they interact with kidney function.

 

Site of Action and Kidney Function:

 

  • Thiazide diuretics primarily act on the distal convoluted tubule in the kidney. They inhibit the sodium-chloride symporter, leading to increased excretion of sodium and chloride, and consequently, water.
  • In advanced CKD, particularly when the eGFR (estimated glomerular filtration rate) falls below 30 mL/min, the kidney function is significantly impaired. Traditional thiazides become less effective because they depend on adequate kidney function to reach their site of action and to exert their diuretic effect.

 

Pharmacokinetics of Metolazone:

 

  • Metolazone is classified as a thiazide-like diuretic. Unlike traditional thiazides, it retains its effectiveness even in patients with reduced kidney function.
  • This is because metolazone has additional actions on the proximal tubule of the kidney, where it inhibits sodium reabsorption. This proximal action is not as dependent on kidney function as the action in the distal tubule.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chlorothiazide: This traditional thiazide diuretic is ineffective in patients with significantly reduced kidney function (eGFR <30 mL/min).

 

Option B. Chlorthalidone: Another traditional thiazide diuretic that is not effective in advanced CKD due to its reliance on adequate kidney function to exert its diuretic effect.

 

Option D. Hydrochlorothiazide: Like other traditional thiazides, hydrochlorothiazide is ineffective in patients with severe renal impairment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Metolazone is the preferred thiazide-like diuretic for patients with stage 4 chronic kidney disease and an eGFR of less than 30 mL/min, as it retains its effectiveness even in the presence of significantly reduced kidney function. This is due to its additional action on the proximal tubule, which is less dependent on kidney function.

questions.text: Which of the following proto-oncogenes is not implicated in carcinoma of thyroid? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) p53

 

p53 is a tumor suppressor gene, not a proto-oncogene like other 3 options.

 

Proto-oncogenes are genes that, when mutated or overexpressed, have the potential to cause normal cells to become cancerous by promoting cell growth and division. On the other hand, tumor suppressor genes like p53 work to prevent uncontrolled cell growth. The p53 gene, often referred to as the "guardian of the genome," plays a crucial role in regulating the cell cycle, DNA repair, and apoptosis (programmed cell death). When p53 is mutated, it can no longer effectively suppress tumor growth, leading to the development of cancer. However, p53 is not categorized as a proto-oncogene and is not directly implicated in thyroid carcinoma as an oncogenic driver.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Selected oncogenes, Their Mode of Activation, and Associated Human Tumors

 

 

Ref: Robbins and Cotrans pathologic basis of disease, 8th edition, Pg no 520

questions.text:
Which of the following is used to define dependence?

 

 

  1. Strong desire to use the drug
  2. Priority to use drugs other than any other activity
  3. Increased tolerance
  4. Persistent use of drugs despite knowing the harmful effects
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1, 2, 3, 4

 

According to ICD-11, dependence on any substance is characterized by the following:

 

  • Strong internal drive to use the substance, which the patient is unable to control.
  • Increased priority is given to the use of the substance over other activities, even when it negatively impacts daily life.
  • Tolerance develops, leading the patient to require higher amounts of the substance to achieve the desired effect.
  • Persistent use despite awareness of harmful consequences, where the patient continues using the substance despite recognizing its damaging effects.

 

These signs reflect both psychological and physical aspects of dependence, and they must persist for at least 3 months to establish a diagnosis of dependence.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 1, 2: Incorrect. While the strong desire and prioritizing drug use are part of dependence, increased tolerance and persistent use despite harm are also required to define dependence fully.

 

Option B. 1 only: Incorrect. A strong desire alone is insufficient for defining dependence; other features such as increased tolerance and prioritization of the substance are also required.

 

Option D. 1, 2, 3: Incorrect. This option excludes "persistent use despite harmful effects," which is a key criterion for dependence.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The diagnosis of substance dependence includes multiple criteria, such as a strong desire to use, prioritizing the substance over other activities, developing tolerance, and persistent use despite harmful effects. All these criteria must be present for a diagnosis of dependence.

questions.text: An elderly woman underwent surgical resection of her bowel, and after a few months, she presents with easy fatiguability and tiredness. Blood smear evaluation shows macrocytic anemia. Which of the following bowel resections is least likely to cause this condition? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Duodenum

 

The clinical scenario indicates a diagnosis of macrocytic anemia due to vitamin B12 and/or folate deficiency. The resection of the duodenum is least likely to cause this condition. Vitamin B12 is absorbed in the terminal ileum, and intrinsic factor (IF) secreted by the parietal cells of the stomach is necessary for its absorption. Vitamin B12 is derived from animal products such as red meat, dairy, and eggs. Vitamin B12 deficiency causes megaloblastic anemia with a peripheral smear showing macro-ovalocytes and a hypersegmented neutrophil. In contrast, the jejunum is mainly used in folic acid absorption, and the stomach and ileum are involved in the absorption of vitamin B12.

 

While the duodenum contributes to overall nutrient absorption, vitamin B12 absorption is mainly absorbed in the ileum. So, resection of the duodenum alone might not as severely impact vitamin B12 absorption.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Jejunum: Resection of the jejunum can potentially lead to malabsorption of folic acid, as this is primarily absorbed in the jejunum or ileum.

 

Option C. Ileum: The ileum is a significant site for the absorption of vitamin B12 and is also involved in folic acid absorption. Resection of the ileum can severely disrupt the absorption of these nutrients, leading to macrocytic anemia.

 

Option D. Stomach: The stomach is the site for production of intrinsic factor, required for B12 absorption.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is correct regarding the tumor shown in the radiograph? (INICET NOVEMBER 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Epiphyseal

 

GIANT-CELL TUMOR (Osteoclastoma):

 

  • It is bone lesion of uncertain origin, most commonly seen in distal femur, proximal tibia, proximal humerus and distal radius.
  • Most commonly seen in 20-40 years of age, after epiphyseal fusion.
  • There is a slight female predominance.
  • Histology:
    • Multinucleated giant cells are seen on a background of stromal cells with little or no visible intercellular tissue.
    • The osteoclast giant cells are the malignant cells, which induce the proliferation of mononuclear macrophage-lineage cells, hence the dividing cell population is the mononuclear cells which form the matrix.
  • GCT has egg shell crackling on palpation.
  • Although these tumors typically are benign, pulmonary metastases occur in approximately 3% of patients.
  • Malignant giant cell tumors represent less than 5% of total GCT.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Most commonly presents with pain, with or without swelling
    • Pathological fracture occurs in 10-15% of cases
    • Pulmonary metastasis occurs in 4% of cases, but they usually regress spontaneously.
  • Radiological features:
    • Eccentric lytic lesion at epiphyseal region, bounded by subchondral bone plate, with soap bubble appearance without any calcifications & reactive sclerosis.
    • Biopsy is necessary for confirming the diagnosis.
  • Treatment:
    • Curettage and ‚Äòstripping‚Äô of the cavity, followed by swabbing with hydrogen peroxide or by the application of liquid nitrogen.
    • More aggressive tumors and recurrent lesions: Excision followed by bone grafting.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 30% malignant transformation. This is incorrect. Pulmonary metastases occur in approximately 3% of patients. Malignant giant cell tumors represent less than 5% of total GCT.

 

Option C. Ground glass opacity is diagnostic. This is incorrect. Ground glass opacity of the bone is seen in fibrous dysplasia.

 

Option D. Radiotherapy is the treatment. This is incorrect. The mainstay of treatment of GCT is curettage and stripping of the cavity. More aggressive tumors are treated by excision and bone grafting.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Giant cell tumors are epiphyseal tumors of the long bones.

questions.text: A patient presents with cough, cold, fever, and malaise associated with weight loss and ascites. The patient does not have any evidence of cirrhosis and her coagulation profile is normal. Ascitic fluid analysis showed elevated adenosine deaminase. What can be done next? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Start ATT

 

In countries with a high prevalence of tuberculosis, such as India, the presence of elevated adenosine deaminase (ADA) in ascitic fluid is highly suggestive of abdominal tuberculosis (TB). ADA is a useful diagnostic marker for TB, particularly when its levels are significantly elevated (e.g., above 39 IU/L). Given the clinical context of weight loss, fever, and ascites, along with a high ADA level, it is reasonable to initiate anti-tubercular therapy (ATT) without further invasive testing. Starting ATT and monitoring the patient's response is an effective and practical approach, especially in resource-limited settings. This strategy avoids unnecessary invasive procedures like peritoneal biopsy, which should be reserved for cases where there is doubt about the diagnosis or if the patient does not respond to initial therapy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Peritoneal Biopsy: While peritoneal biopsy is the gold standard for diagnosing peritoneal TB, it is invasive and resource-intensive. In high-prevalence areas, where elevated ADA levels strongly suggest TB, initiating ATT is preferred.

 

Option C. Observation: Given the significant clinical symptoms and elevated ADA levels, mere observation is not appropriate. Delay in treatment could lead to worsening of the patient‚Äôs condition.

 

Option D. Laparotomy: Laparotomy is an invasive surgical procedure and is not warranted for diagnosing TB when non-invasive methods like ADA testing and clinical presentation strongly suggest the disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In high-prevalence countries for tuberculosis, elevated adenosine deaminase (ADA) in ascitic fluid, along with clinical signs, is sufficient to start anti-tubercular therapy (ATT) without the need for invasive procedures.

choices.text: Previous ectopic pregnancy
Previous history of abortion

questions.text: Which of the following would be considered as an absolute contraindication for insertion of copper T to a patient? (INICET NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Unmotivated patient

 

Inserting a copper T intrauterine device (IUD) requires the patient to be motivated and consent to the procedure. An unmotivated patient or one who does not consent should never undergo the procedure. This is because the successful use of an IUD requires patient understanding, willingness to comply with follow-up care, and adherence to guidelines for managing any potential side effects or complications.

 

Absolute contraindications for the use of copper IUDs include:

 

  • Unexplained uterine or vaginal bleeding
  • Post-abortal sepsis, puerperal sepsis, current pelvic inflammatory disease (PID), or genital tuberculosis
  • Cancers such as endometrial cancer, cervical cancer, and gestational trophoblastic neoplasia
  • Large fibroids distorting the uterine cavity or Mullerian anomalies distorting the uterine cavity

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Menorrhagia: While menorrhagia is a relative contraindication, as the copper IUD can exacerbate heavy menstrual bleeding, it is not an absolute contraindication.

 

Option C. Previous ectopic pregnancy: A history of ectopic pregnancy is a consideration but not an absolute contraindication for copper IUD use.

 

Option D. Previous history of abortion: A previous history of abortion is not an absolute contraindication for the insertion of a copper IUD.

 

Educational Objective:

 

An unmotivated patient or one who does not consent is an absolute contraindication for the insertion of a copper T intrauterine device (IUD).

 

Ref: Dutta’s textbook of gynecology 6th edition pg 480

questions.text: Positive charge in thick ascending loop of Henle is maintained by recirculation of which cation: (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) K+

 

In the thick ascending loop of Henle, the maintenance of positive charge is primarily achieved through the recirculation of potassium ions (K+).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. H+ (Hydrogen ions): Hydrogen ions play a role in regulating the pH of urine but are not primarily responsible for maintaining positive charge in the thick ascending loop of Henle.

 

Option B. Na+ (Sodium ions): Sodium ions are actively reabsorbed in the thick ascending loop of Henle but are not the primary cation responsible for maintaining positive charge in this segment.

 

Option C. NH4+ (Ammonium ions): Ammonium ions are involved in acid-base regulation in the kidneys but are not the primary cation responsible for maintaining positive charge in the thick ascending loop of Henle.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The thick ascending loop of Henle (TAL) is impermeable to water but there is active reabsorption of Na, Cl and K. The cotransporter in membrane of TAL is responsible for reabsorption of 1/3 of both Na and Cl in the body. On the basolateral side there is Na/K ATPase pump which throws sodium out and K in. This K+ is transported back into lumen through Renal outer medullary K+ channel (ROMK) channel for it to be recirculated.

 

 

Ref- https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4220766/

questions.text: Skin manifestations caused by the drug administered for amebic dysentery are due to ______.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Fixed drug eruption

 

The skin manifestations are most commonly due to metronidazole, which is associated with fixed drug eruption (FDE).

 

Although maculopapular rashes can also be seen with metronidazole, the incidence of a fixed drug eruption is higher with metronidazole.

 

Fixed drug eruptions are characterized by sharply demarcated, dull red to brown lesions. They typically occur on the lips, hands, legs, face, genitalia, and oral mucosa, and can cause a burning sensation. These lesions are usually solitary or few in number and recur at the same location when the patient is re-exposed to the drug.

 

FDE is a type of delayed hypersensitivity reaction. Drugs like NSAIDs and paracetamol are some of the most common culprits causing FDE.

 

Drug-specific clinical patterns of FDE:

 

  • NSAIDs: Lips and genitals
  • Tetracycline/Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole: Genitals
  • Metamizole: Trunk and extremities
  • Carbocysteine: Face

 

Diagnosis is based on clinical history and lesion morphology. The first step in management is discontinuation of the offending drug. The image below shows a well-defined hyperpigmented patch of a fixed drug eruption.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Urticaria: Urticaria is characterized by hives or raised, itchy welts, which is a different presentation than FDE. It is typically not associated with metronidazole in the context of amebic dysentery treatment.

 

Option C. Maculopapular rash: While maculopapular rashes can occur with metronidazole, fixed drug eruption is more commonly associated with it in cases of amebic dysentery treatment.

 

Option D. Atopic dermatitis: Atopic dermatitis presents as chronic, itchy, and inflamed skin, often linked to allergens or irritants. This is not related to drug reactions like fixed drug eruptions seen with metronidazole.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fixed drug eruption (FDE) is a common drug reaction, especially with medications like metronidazole. It presents as sharply demarcated, recurrent lesions at the same location upon re-exposure to the drug. Recognizing this pattern is essential for diagnosis and discontinuation of the offending drug.

questions.text: Identify the fracture site in the X-ray shown below. (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 4th, 5th, 6th rib

 

The given X-ray shows the fracture of the 4th, 5th, 6th rib.

 

 

Tricks to counting ribs:

 

  • The horizontal oriented ribs are posterior ribs
  • The oblique oriented ribs are anterior ribs
  • Count below from 1st rib one after another

 

Counting ribs on a chest X-ray in the posteroanterior (PA) view can be done by locating the clavicle and 1st rib. Count downward from the first rib as you move along.

 

 

Differentiating between posterior and anterior ribs on an X-ray can be done by looking at direction of the Rib Curvature. On a posterior-anterior (PA) chest X-ray, anterior ribs typically exhibit a downward convex curvature as they wrap around the chest wall. In contrast, the posterior ribs have an upward concave curvature as they extend posteriorly towards the spine.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

When identifying rib fractures on a chest X-ray, start counting from the first rib, which is located just beneath the clavicle, and follow downward. Note the curvature of the ribs: anterior ribs curve downward and outward, while posterior ribs curve upward. This method helps in accurately locating and identifying the specific ribs involved in fractures or other abnormalities.
